That would make me the quarterman. It just doesn't have the same ring to it. Cut me in half and I won't be able to give the signal. No signal, no plan. No plan and Stannis Baratheon sacks this city, takes the Iron Throne, puts your pinched little head atop a gate somewhere. It might be quite amusing, except that my head would be up there, too. I've never much liked my head, but I don't want to see it removed just yet.
Archers to their marks.
Hold fast.
Hold fast.
He's a serious man, Stannis Baratheon.
Rain fire on them.
Hound, form a welcome party for any Baratheon troop that manages to touch solid ground. Pod, run to the King's Gate. Bring any men guarding it here, now.
Can I get you some iced milk and a nice bowl of raspberries, too?
You're on the wrong side of the wall.
You're Kingsguard, Clegane. You must beat them back or they're going to take this city. Your king's city.
If you won't defend your own city, why should they?
Lead. Get down there and lead your people against the invaders who want to kill them.
I'll lead the attack. I'll lead the attack!
Pod, my helmet. Ser Mandon, you will bear the king's banner. Men, form up. Men Men! They say I'm half a man. But what does that make the lot of you?
There's another way out. I'm going to show you. We'll come out behind them and fuck them in their arses.

Don't fight for your king and don't fight for his kingdoms. Don't fight for honor. Don't fight for glory. Don't fight for riches, because you won't get any. This is your city Stannis means to sack. That's your gate he's ramming. If he gets in, it will be your houses he burns, your gold he steals, your women he will rape.
Those are brave men knocking at our door. Let's go kill them.
Attack!
Oh, fuck me.

3.text: Pod?
What are they doing here?
No, I don't think so.
They stay outside.
Why are you here?
The man who cut me lost more than his nose.
Thanks to Father. Of course, it wasn't a rebel who tried to kill me.
Grand Maester Pycelle made the same joke. You must be proud to be as funny as a man whose balls brush his knees.
How do you know that?

What do I want from him? He's my father. Do I need to want something? I'm sure he loves me dearly, as any father loves his child, his baby boy. Yet he hasn't come to visit once since arriving in King's Landing. I lay here, my face split in half, but Father never came.
Why do you care what I want from him?
Slandered? When?
You did have your guards beat her. A girl of nine, I believe.
She lost an eye, if I remember correctly.
It's not slander if it's true.
Why are you so nervous about what I'm going to say to Father?
Any lies in particular?
Still makes me more clever than you.
A number of people in this city want to kill me. You're here to protect me.
Do you grow bored protecting me?
Poor? Poor? Under my patronage you've become a knight, you've served as Commander of the City Watch.
I'm sure you filled your pockets.
I thought we were friends.
How much?
Double?
I don't even know how much I'm paying you now.
( sighs ) The badge looks good on you. Almost as good as it looked on me. Are you enjoying your new position?
I was very happy as Hand of the King.
It wasn't your bed at the time.
Occasionally I drank with the harlots.
Why does everyone assume I want something? Can't I simply visit with my beloved father? My beloved father who somehow forgot to visit his wounded son after he fell on the battlefield.

I organized the defense of this city while you held court in the ruins of Harrenhal. I led the foray when the enemies were at the gate while your grandson, the king, quivered in fear behind the walls. I bled in the mud for our family. And as my reward, I was trundled off to some dark little cell. But what do I want? A little bloody gratitude would be a start.

I want what is mine by right. Jaime is your eldest son, heir to your lands and titles. But he is a Kingsguard, forbidden from marriage or inheritance. The day Jaime put on the white cloak, he gave up his claim to Casterly Rock. I am your son and lawful heir.
It is mine by right.
Why?
Hmm. Ser Eldrick Sarsfield and Lord Desmond Crakehall. Ser Eldrick Sarsfield and Lord Desmond Crakehall.
I have a list.
For laughing at me? Do I look like Joffrey to you? No, death seems a bit extreme. Fear of death, on the other hand--
My lady, people have been laughing at me far longer than they've been laughing at you. I'm the Halfman, the Demon Monkey, the Imp.
The disgraced daughter and the Demon Monkey. We're perfect for each other.
Who? Whom?
Ah. I could speak to Lord Varys and learn their perversions. Anyone named Desmond Crakehall must be a pervert.
I am the Imp. I have certain standards to maintain.
Lady Sansa!
Why sheep shift?
My lady--
Killed a few puppies today?
'Roslin caught a fine fat trout. Her brothers gave her a pair of wolf pelts for her wedding. Signed Walder Frey.' Is that bad poetry or is it supposed to mean something?
No. She is no longer yours to torment.
Oh, I'm a monster. Perhaps you should speak to me more softly, then. Monsters are dangerous and just now kings are dying like flies.
You just sent the most powerful man in Westeros to bed without his supper.
A treasonous statement. Joffrey is king.
No. I think armies give you power.
Robb Stark had one, never lost a battle, and you defeated him all the same.

Oh, I know. Walder Frey gets all the credit. Or the blame, I suppose, depending on your allegiance. Walder Frey is many things, but a brave man? No. He never would have risked such an action if he didn't have certain assurances.
I'm all for cheating. This is war.
So that's why you did it? To save lives?
The northerners will never forget.
Do you think she'll open her legs for me after I tell her how we murdered her mother and brother?
I will not rape her.
Use small words. I'm not as bright as you.
(smirks)
No, it's a very good lesson. Only it's easy for you to preach utter devotion to family when you're making all the decisions.
When have you ever done something that wasn't in your interest but solely for the benefit of the family?
Sansa.
Keep up.
It's not easy being drunk all the time. Everyone would do it if it were easy.
She doesn't deserve this.
There's nothing worse than a late-blooming philosopher.
Will you be facing your marriage to Ser Loras with the same philosophical spirit?
I seem to remember saying something similar about my own marriage.
So you can tell Father it was you who finally talked me into it?
You have children. How happy would you say you are?
Even Joffrey?
How long does it go on?
Every time we deal with an enemy, we create two more.
We've spoken of this. You cannot come here.
Did anyone see you? No.
You sure? My father does not make idle threats. Having you killed would be the high point of his week. You have to be absolutely certain.
All right. What is this problem?
Baelish doesn't have friends.
Oh, Ros? The redhead?
I try to know as many people as I can. You never know which one you'll need.
Yes, well, we shouldn't be judgmental about these things.
Oh, please. All right, yes, I fucked her once. Twice.
But since I met you, my lady, I've been with no one else.
Not as much as I like you, obviously, or she'd be the one torturing me right now. What did she say about Littlefinger?
Is there an idiot in any village who trusts Littlefinger?
We can't. Now that the Lannisters have discarded her, Sansa will have many suitors. A great beauty with a very old name.
Yes, she is, objectively, very. Her face is quite pleasing-to other men and to women, people in general. But not to me, of course. I only have eyes for you.
I don't even want to talk about her.
Only because you're making me.
This is cruel and unfair. Cruelly unfair.
Hmm, yes.
Only if you stop. But you mustn't come here again.
Do you hear me? You've come to a dangerous place full of dangerous people. Dangerous people.
Intimate. Lovely table. Better chairs than the old small council chamber. Conveniently close to your own quarters. I like it.

Far be it from me to hinder true love, but Lord Baelish's absence would present certain problems. The royal wedding may end up being the most expensive event in living memory. Summer has ended, hard days lie ahead. Not a good time to leave the crown's finances unattended.
Master of Coin?
I'm quite good at spending money, but a lifetime of outrageous wealth hasn't taught me much about managing it.
A surprising place to keep the royal ledgers.
Not for bastards.
Pod. Pod. Take them outside. I'll be there in a moment.
Only my life. Not all that significant, I'm afraid.
If only the Master of Coin had such power.
Oh, that. Of course. A simple misunderstanding.
We don't. I did fuck her once.
But we don't.
Why don't you ask her? Any advice for me on my new position?
If I had a gold dragon for every time I heard that joke, I'd be richer than you are.
Good point.
I've tried quite a few. Well, lots of work to do. Enjoy the Eyrie.
You think all reading is dull reading.
The secret history of the Seven Kingdoms is written in these pages.
Unless he made it all up, yes. Podrick, do keep up.
Podrick.

After a long consultation with my colleague Ser Bronn, I finally found a suitable reward for the services you've provided over and above what might be considered reasonable. Tell me, Pod, have you ever been with a woman?
Wonderful. Genna specializes in first-timers.
A fair enough repayment for putting your spear through my would-be killer's face, wouldn't you say?
Now, as it happens, Marei is quite the spear handler herself. She's here to thank you for staying by my side as the battle raged all around me.
Kayla is famous from here to Volantis in certain circles. One of four women in the world who can perform a proper Meereenese Knot.
She's here to thank you for being a thoroughly respectful fellow who's never once failed to address me as 'my lord.
Be back in time for my supper.
For years I've heard that Littlefinger is a magician. Whenever the crown needs money, he rubs his hands together and, poof, mountains of gold.
No.
Worse, he's borrowing it.
We can't afford to pay it back, that's what's wrong with it. The crown owes millions to my father.
Forgive a debt, my father? For a man of the world, you're strangely naive.
Well Ahem! The basic principle is I lend you money, and after an agreed upon period of time, you return it with interest.
Well, you have to.

This is why I don't lend you money. Anyway, it's not my father I'm worried about. It's the Iron Bank of Braavos. We owe them tens of millions. If we fail to repay these loans, the bank will fund our enemies. One way or another, they always get their gold back.
Ah, the return of the conquering hero. Does he have a little jaunt in his step?
You were gone a long time. I trust you got your money's worth. Or should I say my money's worth?
Oh, it was a gift, Podrick. This is more than I give you in a year.
Oh, then it's much more than I give you in a year.
Have you ever known a whore to turn down gold? They were happy enough to take it when I gave it to them.
What did you do to them?
And they seemed to like these things?
Only they weren't paid.
Is that what you're telling us? {PODRICK doesn't deny it.
Sit down, Podrick.
We're going to need details. Copious details.
I hope we might speak. In confidence.
About the events of the Blackwater. Perhaps this is the wrong time?
I thought one of your little birds might have knowledge of my sister's intentions to--
I didn't inherit Littlefinger's spies along with his position, I'm afraid. Which is why I'm coming to you. I need proof.
I need to know.
I don't know. Do I?
Yes, ahem. I feel the need for actual revenge against the actual person who tried to have me killed. Which will require a degree of influence, which--
The sorcerer.
Thank you for seeing me, my lady. I had hoped we might discuss a few financial matters.
It's the royal wedding. I'm told you had a hand in planning it.
It's shaping up to be a very involved affair. The word extravagant has been used.
I understand that.
But, as Master of Coin, it falls upon me to calculate the cost for the crown. As of now, it's a huge expense.
And we're at war, Lady Olenna.
Yes, and maintaining supply lines--
And we are so grateful for your contributions which are necessary for the preservation of the realm.
I would.
(nods)
My lady--
Quite sufficient. Thank you.
Give me that.
What's she doing here?
You'll be pleased to learn that after one conversation with Olenna Tyrell, I've saved the crown hundreds of thousands on this wedding.
I'm Master of Coin. Saving money is important.
(to Cersei) Stop that. You're making me uncomfortable.
Very well. She's a lovely girl. Missing some of Loras' favorite bits, but I'm sure they'll make do.
It wasn't my best, but--
Sansa is the key to the North? I seem to remember she has an older brother.
The Tyrell army is helping us to win this war. Do you really think it's wise to refuse them?
And how do we do that?
Wonderful.
You can't mean it.
Joffrey has made this poor girl's life miserable since the day he took her father's head. Now she's finally free of him and you give her to me? That's cruel even for you.
She's a child!
And if I refuse?
I was wed. Or don't you remember?
I don't suppose there's anything we can do about this.
It's hard to say which of the four of us is getting the worst of this arrangement. Probably Sansa. Though Loras will certainly come to know a deep and singular misery.
On a boat you built.
I'm your family. A member of your family who has actively contributed to that family's survival. Whether or not you or Father or anyone else wants to admit it.

Trying to have me killed is an odd way of saying thank you. There are two people in King's Landing who can give an order to a Kingsguard. Did you or did you not order Ser Mandon to kill me during the Battle of the Blackwater?

The impulse I understand. He hates me because I'm the only one who tells him what he really is. So, fair enough. He wants me dead. But his stupidity? He could have had me poisoned and no one would have known. But the king orders a Kingsguard to murder the Hand of the King in full view of his own army. The boy's an idiot.
I want you to tell me if my life is still in danger.
Seven kingdoms united in fear of Tywin Lannister.
You may escape, at least. Once Jaime gets back, Ser Loras may come down with a terrible case of sword through bowels.
Jaime or not, I'm truly fucked.
I beg your pardon, my lady.
Yes, it should be quite a wedding. I need to speak with you, Lady Sansa.
Alone, if I may.
Sometimes we think we want to hear something and it's only afterwards when it's too late that we realize we wished we'd heard it under entirely different circumstances.
How to begin? It's-- this-- this-- this is awkward.
She's a child.
A tall child.
Not that young.
Older.
Shae isn't going to like it.
I should never have told you about that.
Two women to despise me and a whole kingdom to join them.
I don't pay you to put evil notions in my head. The ones already there don't need company.
Solid gold from the mines outside Lannisport. Smithed in Casterly Rock.
You could buy a ship with these.
What?
Of course you're not going anywhere.
I didn't ask for this marriage. I didn't want it.
That doesn't mean that--this is duty, not desire.
I don't have a choice. My father--
What would I do there? Juggle? I am a Lannister of Casterly Rock.
My feelings for you have not changed. I will marry Sansa Stark and do my duty by her.
I swear to you it will not be like that.
I will buy you a good home somewhere in the city. You will have fine clothes, guards to keep you safe, servants. Any children we might have will be well provided for.
Listen. Listen to me, my lady.
You are. You'll always be my lady.
Lady Sansa.
Oh, yes. The husband of your dreams. But you do look glorious. Perhaps we could have a moment alone. Do you mind? Podrick, could you escort Lady Stark's handmaiden?
My lady, I want you to know I didn't ask for this.

No, don't. You don't have to speak to me as a prisoner anymore. You won't be a prisoner after today. You'll be my wife. I suppose that's a different kind of prison. I just wanted to say-- I'm just trying to say very badly-- I just-- just want to say I know how you feel.
You're right. I have no idea how you feel. And you have no idea how I feel.
But I promise you one thing, my lady. I won't ever hurt you. Do you drink wine?
Well, today you have to.
Could you-
Thank you.
(snorts)
Of course. Of course. En--enjoy.
Rather less than I plan to be. Isn't it a man's duty to be drunk at his own wedding?
And?
What did you once call me? A drunken little lust-filled beast.
There you have it. Nothing to worry about. Drinking and lust, no man can match me in these things. I am the god of tits and wine. I shall build a shrine to myself at the next brothel I visit.
There will be no bedding ceremony.
There will be no bedding ceremony.
Then you'll be fucking your own bride with a wooden cock.
A bad joke, Your Grace. Made out of envy of your own royal manhood. Mine is so small. My poor wife won't even know I'm there.
I am. Guilty. But-- but it is my wedding night.
My tiny drunk cock and I have a job to do. Come, wife.
I vomited on a girl once in the middle of the act. Not proud of it. But I think honesty is important between a man and wife, don't you agree? Come, I'll tell you all about it. Put you in the mood.
Tyrion, Sansa. My name is Tyrion.
Nothing was ever wiser.
Astoundingly long.
Neck. You have one. How old are you exactly?
Well, talk won't make you any older. My lord father has commanded me to consummate this marriage.
Stop. I can't. I could, I won't.
If my father wants someone to get fucked, I know where he can start. I won't share your bed. Not until you want me to.
And so my watch begins.
You really ought to knock.

4.text: Please don't.
This is the Prince of Dorne we're waiting for, not one of your sellsword friends.
There's bad blood between the Martells of Dorne and the Lannisters of Casterly Rock. Has been for years.
No need for cynicism. I happen to be an accomplished diplomat.
Ah, here we are.
Can you read the sigils?
Boy knows his Dornish Houses.
And House Martell, a red sun pierced by a spear?

Well met, my lords. His Grace King Joffrey welcomes you in his name. My lord father, the King's Hand, sends his greetings as well. I am Tyrion Lannister of Casterly Rock, Master of Coin. Forgive me. I don't see Prince Doran in your company.
(Nods.) Yes, the king will be delighted to enjoy the company of a warrior as renowned as Prince Oberyn at his wedding feast.
And where is Prince Oberyn?
Very well. My lords, these fine men from the City Watch will escort you to your quarters in the Red Keep.
You must be weary after such a long journey.
We must find Prince Oberyn before he kills somebody or several somebodies.
You're famous for fucking half of Westeros. You just arrived at the capital after two weeks of bad roads, where would you go?
Prince Oberyn, forgive the intrusion. We heard there might be...
trouble.
I'm here to welcome you to the capital.
If there's anything I can do to make your stay...
Oh, I partook. Now I'm married.
Prince Oberyn, if I may, a word in private?
Oh, they take all kinds.
The king is very grateful that you traveled all this way for his wedding.
Well, speaking as a fellow second son, I have grown rather used to being the family insult.
Why did you come to King's Landing, Prince Oberyn?
I thought we were speaking truth.
I wasn't actually present.
I've heard rumors.
I wasn't there. I don't know what happened.
My lady, you do need to eat.
If I could have a moment alone with my wife.
I can't let you starve.
I swore to protect you.
My lady, I am your husband. Let me help you.
I don't know, but I can try.
I could get you essence of nightshade to help you sleep.

What happened to your family was a terrible crime. I didn't know your brother. He seemed like a good man, but I didn't know him. Your mother, on the other hand, I admired her. She wanted to have me executed, but I admired her. She was a strong woman. And she was fierce when it came to protecting her children. Sansa. Your mother would want you to carry on. You know it's true.
Of course. Of course. Prayer can be helpful, I hear.
What are you doing?
How many times have I told you? You can't visit me here.
Of course I haven't forgotten.
Things are a bit tense right now.
My nephew the king wants to murder me. My wife hates me because my father murdered her family. Oberyn Martell wants to murder everyone whose last name is Lannister.
I told you. It's not a good time.
Shae.
Love her? I barely know her. She's a child. She despises me.
Of course I don't love her.
Ship you away?
What in the world are you talking about?
Shh. I don't know what you're talking about.
Oh, get on with it you son of a whore.
What’re you doing?
Who’s helping you?
Varys?
I suppose this is goodbye, then.
Jaime, thank you. For my life.
I’m sorry. I’m sorry.
All my life, you’ve wanted me dead.
I loved her.
Shae.
I murdered her. With my own hands.
It doesn’t matter?
Say that word again.
I am your son, and you sentenced me to die. You knew I didn’t poison Joffrey, but you sentenced me all the same. Why?
I can’t go back there. She’s in there.
I am your son. I have always been your son.
Your new hand, it's nicer than the old one. Wouldn't you agree, Pod?
You're not eating. Why is no one eating? My wife wastes away and my brother starves himself.
You lost a hand, not a stomach. Try the boar. Cersei can't get enough of it since one killed Robert for her.
A toast. To the proud Lannister children. The dwarf, the cripple, and the mother of madness.
It's only wine.
What about your left?
You're the Lord Commander now. Command. Let others do the fighting. When was the last time Father used a sword?
Train, then. Learn to fight with your other hand.
You need a proper, discreet swordsman. As it happens, I have just the one.
Lord Varys. Breakfasting with the king?
Oh, to be foreign.
So I'm guilty of being seen with my own wife's handmaiden. My father will ask you if there's anything more and you'll tell him some clever lie.
Forgive me if I don't weep for you.
She won't leave. I've told her this is a dangerous place so many times, she no longer believes it.
"The Lives of Four Kings." Grand Maester Kaeth's history of the reigns of Daeron the Young Dragon, Baelor the Blessed, Aegon the Unworthy, and Daeron the Good. A book every king should read.
Don't.
Don't call me that.
I'm afraid our friendship can't continue.
There's a ship waiting in the harbor bound for Pentos.
I'm a married man. My wife has suffered a great deal, as you well know. I don't want her to suffer anymore on my account. I need to uphold my vows.
I need to do right by her.
By our children.
I'm not afraid.
Shae.
You're a whore! Sansa is fit to bear my children and you are not. I can't be in love with a whore. I can't have children with a whore. How many men have you been with? 500? 5,000?
I have enjoyed my time with all of them and I have enjoyed my time with you most of all. But now that time is over.
You'll have a comfortable life in Pentos. Bronn will escort you to your ship.
Better her than you.
You saw her board the ship?
You saw the ship sail away?
How do you know?
There's someone following you?
Hello.
My lady. My lady.
We'll have to find another way to thank the king.

One taste of combat was enough for me, Your Grace. I would like to keep what remains of my face. I think you should fight him. This was but a poor imitation of your own bravery on the field of battle. I speak as a firsthand witness. Climb down from the high table with your new Valyrian sword and show everyone how a true king wins his throne. Be careful, though. This one is clearly mad with lust. It would be a tragedy for the king to lose his virtue hours before his wedding night.
A fine vintage. Shame that it spilled.
Your Grace does me a great honor.
Let's find out.
I thought I might change out of these wet clothes, Your Grace.
If it please Your Grace, Lady Sansa is very tired.
Your Grace?
Podrick. Apologies for the stench.
A noble effort.
You're a good lad. Any word of Shae?
I suppose that's a good thing. What are they saying about me out there?
Do you believe I murdered Joffrey?

No. Gods, no. The world is a better place without him, but I had nothing to do with it. I would like to think if I were arranging a royal assassination, I'd plan it in such a way that I wouldn't be standing there gawking like a fool when the king died. Trial in a fortnight. Have they announced the judges yet?
Of course.
Who will vote exactly as my father tells him to vote.
Oberyn? Give it to my father. He never fails to take advantage of a family tragedy.
Oh, I can call my own witnesses? How generous of them. Very well, my wife. Sansa.
Gone?

No one had more 'cause to kill Joffrey than Sansa, but the girl is no assassin. Whoever killed the king wanted me to lose my head for it. And with my wife's disappearance, it makes me seem that much more guilty. Podrick.
They'll be following you now.

I don't know. They. They. The ominous they. The man pulling the strings. Or woman. My father. Maybe Joffrey was too much work for him. Sweet Tommen will be so much easier to handle. Whenever something bad happens to me, I assume it's my sister that had a hand in it. But say what you will of Cersei, she loves her children. She is the only one I'm certain had nothing to do with this murder. Which makes it unique as King's Landing murders go.
Varys could vouch for me if he dared.
Of course. Fetch Bronn. I have a job for him.
Why not?
And my brother? Will they at least allow me to see Jaime?
Ser Podrick Payne? Has a nice ring to it. What did you tell him?
Are you going to accept their offer?
Testifying against me wasn't a suggestion. If they can't tempt you with honey, they'll choose something less sweet.
Pod, the trial's in a fortnight. They'll want an answer before that.
I will not have you dying on my behalf. Do you hear me? If I have to take that long walk to the executioner's block, I don't want to see your head already mounted.
Pod, I am giving you an order. Go and find my brother. Tell him I need him. And get yourself out of King's Landing before it's too late. Pod! This is farewell.
Pod. There has never lived a more loyal squire.
Is that supposed to make me feel better?
It's complicated, yes. So how is our sister?
Her son?

My trial for regicide.Yes, I know. I know the whole bloody country thinks I'm guilty. I know that one of my three judges has wished me dead more times than I can count. And that judge is my father. As for Cersei, well, she's probably working on a way to avoid a trial altogether by having me killed.
So, should I turn around and close my eyes?
The Kingslayer brothers. You like it? I like it. You're really asking if I killed your son?
Well, you could set me free.
Then there's really nothing else to say.
Sorry, I'd forgotten. I'd hate for you to do something inappropriate.
Except I didn't do it.
Sansa couldn't have done this. She had more reason than anyone in the Seven Kingdoms. Do you think it's a coincidence she disappeared the same night Joffrey died?
No, but... Sansa's not a killer. Not yet, anyway.
Let me guess, I've been pardoned.
Really?
Well, we mustn't disappoint Father.
No.
Not that I know of.
Choked on his pigeon pie.
Or the pigeons. Just leave me out of it.
Oh, why don't you tell them what Joffrey was doing?
Pointing a loaded crossbow at Sansa Stark while you tore at her clothes and beat her.
(shakes his head)
Father, may I ask the witness one question?
You once said that without me, this city would have faced certain defeat. You said the histories would never mention me, but you would not forget. Have you forgotten, Lord Varys?
Not going well, is it?
Oh, you think so?
Ned Stark was promised the same thing and we both know how that turned out.
How do you know?
(nods)
Shae. Please don't.
Father, I wish to confess. I wish... to confess.
I saved you. I saved this city and all your worthless lives. I should have let Stannis kill you all.
Yes, Father. I'm guilty. Guilty. Is that what you want to hear?
No, of that I'm innocent. I'm guilty of a far more monstrous crime. I am guilty of being a dwarf.
Oh, yes, I am. I've been on trial for that my entire life.
Nothing but this-- I did not do it. I did not kill Joffrey, but I wish that I had.
(To Cersei) Watching your vicious bastard die gave me more relief than 1,000 lying whores.
(To the crowd) I wish I was the monster you think I am. I wish I had enough poison for the whole pack of you. I would gladly give my life to watch you all swallow it.
I will not give my life for Joffrey's murder. And I know I'll get no justice here. So I will let the gods decide my fate. I demand a trial by combat.
I'm sorry, what am I grateful for? The opportunity to live and die at the Wall as punishment for a crime I did not commit?
Of course it's a joke, just not a very funny one. I couldn't-- I couldn't listen to her standing there telling her lies. I couldn't do it.

Yes, I fell in love with a whore. And I was stupid enough to think that she had fallen in love with me. That deal you made, it was everything Father wanted. You do see that? He gets you back as his heir. The future Lord of the Rock. And he ships me off to Castle Black, out of sight at last. All so perfect. It felt good to take that from him. He knows I'm innocent and he's willing to sacrifice me anyway. He's willing to sacrifice any of us. Not you. You're the golden son. You could kill a king, lose a hand, fuck your own sister, you'll always be the golden son.
At least I got to tell them what they really are.
Don't give up on me just yet. I survived one trial by combat, even though you weren't there to save me.
Where's your sense of adventure? Even if you lose, imagine the look on Father's face when you fall.
Our family name snuffed out with a single swing of the sword.
Well... Bronn fought for me once, he'll do it again. If he wins, I expect I'll be in his debt for the rest of my life.
Will you find him for me? Who does Cersei plan on naming as a champion? I hope it's Ser Meryn Trant. I'd enjoy watching Bronn disembowel that pompous child beater.
You have new clothes.
I sent for you days ago.
Doing what?
Lollys Stokeworth? She doesn't strike me as your sort of girl.
She's dim-witted.
When my sister arranged this love match, did she mention that Lollys has an older sister?
And you understand the rules of inheritance?
She still gets Castle Stokeworth when her father dies.
(scoffs.)
You and my sister deserve each other. Why did you bother to come here?
Is it two wives you want or two castles?
I'm a bit short on castles at the moment. But I can offer you gold and gratitude.
You might be surprised. A Lannister always pays his debts.
My wife is heir to Winterfell. If I emerge from this with my head still on my shoulders, I may one day rule the North in her name. I could carve you out a big piece of it.
Does he frighten you so much?
Because you're my friend.
I understand.
Why are you sorry? Because you're an evil bastard with no conscience and no heart? That's what I liked about you in the first place.
Yes, we did.
I suppose I'll have to kill the Mountain myself. Won't that make for a great song?
I imagined you'd be back at the brothel at this hour.
Mm, do tell. I've got every kind of filth down here except the kind I like.
Oh.
Making honest feelings do dishonest work is one of her many gifts.
She didn't need to bother you. It looks as though I've taken care of that myself. The joy she will feel when my head leaves my neck. She's wanted this for a long time.
I think I would have remembered that.
You and my family have more in common than you might admit.
That would have made things so much easier.
Well... sooner or later, Cersei always gets what she wants.
If you want justice, you've come to the wrong place.

Wine always helps. I thank you for it. Trial by combat. Deciding a man's guilt or innocence in the eyes of the gods by having two other men hack each other to pieces. Tells you something about the gods. How much longer?
Do you think Oberyn has a chance? The Red Viper of Dorne. You don't get a name like that unless you're deadly, right?
Oh, he's going to die. I'm going to die.
That's putting it mildly. What's the punishment for regicide? Drawing and quartering? Hanging? Breaking at the wheel?

Seems rather ordinary. And he was my nephew as well, so what is that? Fratricide is brothers. Filicide is sons. Nepoticide. That's the one. Matricide, patricide, infanticide, suicide. There's no kind of killing that doesn't have its own word.
Cousins, you're right. There is no word for cousin killing. Well done. Do you remember cousin Orson? Orson Lannister?
Simple? Used to sit all day in the garden. Crushing beetles with a rock.
Nothing made him happier.
On the contrary. Laughing at another person's misery was the only thing that made me feel like everyone else.
For you. You drifted away.
Yes, other interests. But I stayed with Orson.

I was curious. Why was he smashing all those beetles? What did he get out of it? First thing I did was ask him. "Orson, why are you smashing all those beetles?" He gave me an answer. "Smash the beetles. Smash 'em. Khuu! Khuu! Khuu!" I wasn't deterred. I was the smartest person I knew. Certainly I had the wherewithal to unravel the mysteries that lay at the heart of a moron. So I went to Maester Volarik's library.

Turns out, far too much has been written about great men and not nearly enough about morons. Doesn't seem right. In any case, I found nothing that illuminated the nature of Orson's affliction or the reason behind his relentless beetle slaughter. So I went back to the source. I may not have been able to speak with Orson, but I could observe him, watch him the way men watch animals to come to a deeper understanding of their behavior. *picks up a beetle* And as I watched, I became more and more sure of it. There was something happening there. His face was like the page of a book written in a language I didn't understand. But he wasn't mindless. He had his reasons. And I became possessed with knowing what they were. I began to spend inordinate amounts of time watching him. I would eat my lunch in the garden, chewing my mutton to the music of "khuu, khuu, khuu". And when I wasn't watching him, I was thinking about him. Father droned on about the family legacy and I thought about Orson's beetles. I read the histories of Targaryen conquests. Did I hear dragon wings? No. I heard "khuu, khuu, khuu" and I still couldn't figure out why he was doing it. And I had to know, because it was horrible that all these beetles should be dying for no reason.

I know, I know. But still, it filled me with dread. Piles and piles of them, years and years of them. How many countless living crawling things smashed and dried out and returned to the dirt? In my dreams I found myself standing on a beach made of beetle husks stretching as far as the eye could see. I woke up crying, weeping for their shattered little bodies. I tried to stop Orson once.

He just pushed me aside with a "khuu" and kept on smashing. Every day until that mule kicked him in the chest and killed him. *puts the beetle back on the ground* So what do you think? Why did he do it? What was it all about?
Looks like very light armor.
You could at least wear a helmet. You shouldn't drink before a fight.
It could get you killed. It could get me killed.
Thank the gods.

5.text: I still don’t see why I had to stay in this fucking crate once we set sail.
Do you know what it’s like to stuff your shit through one of those air holes?
Pentos?
Much better.
I don’t think I am anymore. A lord. Are you a lord if you kill your father? I don’t suppose they revoke your nobility for killing a whore. That has to be happen all the time.
In a box. Why stop now?
The future is shit. Just like the past.
Eunuch, the spider, the master of whisperers.
Not for a coward.
You never told me why you set me free.
You could have said no.
Not as dangerous as releasing me. You risked your life, your position, everything. Why? You’re not family, you owe me nothing.
A drunken dwarf will never be the savior of the Seven Kingdoms.
You’re going to have to find another soldier. I’m done with Westeros and Westeros is done with me.
I’m not well-suited for work.
Compassion? Yes. I killed my lover with my bare hands. I shot my own father with a crossbow.
What is it you want exactly?
Where the castles are made of gingerbread and the moats are filled with blackberry wine. The powerful have always preyed on the powerless, that’s how they became powerful in the first place.
I will never sit on the Iron Throne.
Good luck finding him.
Can I drink myself to death on the road to Meereen?

You love her, don’t you? How could you not. Of course, it’s hopeless for the both of you. Sellsword from the fighting pits, a disgraced knight. Neither one of you is fit consort for a queen. But, we always want the wrong woman.
Dwarf. I believe that’s the word. Apologies. My Valyrian is a bit “nostril”.
(Valyrian) “Rusty” (Common Tongue) Thank you.
He’s right. The dragon headed north. If we’re going to find her, that’s where we’re to go.
And I intend to help her do it.
You betrayed her!
And she exiled you, twice, I believe?
Don’t blame me for your crimes, Mormont.
Fine, fine, I suppose he can join us. Just as long as he promises not to kill me in my sleep.
Pardon me?
Not precisely, but I have other skills that’d be very useful--
I have fought. I don’t claim to be a great warrior.
Middling.
And drink. I’ve survived so far.
I suppose there’s no point in asking how you found me.
Well, she didn’t execute me, so that’s a promising start. Now the heroes are off to find her, and I’m stuck here, trying to placate a city on the brink of civil war. Any advice for an old comrade?
If only I knew someone with a vast network of spies.
I did miss you.
There's a bug.
When I agreed to come with you, did I misrepresent my intentions? (finishes his cup of wine) Besides, what is there for me to do inside this fucking box?
I want to take a walk.
She ought to offer her cunt. Best part of her for the best part of me. Well, I suppose a box is as good a place for me as anywhere.
You're right. No point. (realizing) The road to Volantis? You said we were going to Meereen. What's in Volantis?
And what do you hope to find at the end of the road to Meereen?
We've already got a ruler. Everywhere has already got a ruler. Every pile of shit on the side of every road has someone's banner hanging from it.
I didn't rule. I was a servant.
Managed to kill a lot of people.
She wanted me to leave King's Landing. She begged me. I wouldn't go.
'Cause I liked it. Power. Even as a servant. (takes a drink of wine)
I find us repulsive.
You're right. Let's go for a walk.
How many dwarves are there in the world? Is Cersei going to kill them all?
I have to get out of this wheelhouse.
I have to get out of this wheelhouse.
Mm, I have to get out of this wheelhouse.
(Walks over to him). I will not be of any use to Daenerys Targaryen if I lose my mind. I can't remember the last face I saw that wasn't yours.
I'm losing my mind.
Look, we are thousands of miles from Westeros. (Pulls his hood up). What am I? (Varys shakes his head). One more drunk dwarf.
Slaves.
The only red priest we had in King's Landing was Thoros of Myr. This one's much better looking.
Stone men. Good luck stopping this spread of grayscale with prayer. You'd have better luck dancing away the plague. (Varys shushes him worriedly).
We're going to meet the Saviour! You should have told me. Who doesn't want to meet the Saviour?
(Covering his face). Come on. Let's find a brothel.
It's even better luck to suck a dwarf's cock.
See? We blend right in. Just two more travellers, mad with lust.
Curious... hair. (She looks at him).
It appears you're not the only Targaryen supporter.
Well, (Watches her kiss the man), she's taken.
I need to speak to someone with hair.
Hello?
You've got no drink.

Do I look like a man without money? (She looks at him incredulously). Never trust looks. Until quite recently, I was one of the richest men in the world. (She laughs). But who needs wealth when you can make a woman laugh? (Sits down). I always pay my debts, I'm well known for it.
That’s because they’ve never met a queen.
You know how to spot a liar. If I could pick any girl here, I would pick you.
Because you have a skeptical mind.
(After a moment). I'm, I'm sorry, I can't.
I'm not.
Gladly, but this, I can't do. Believe me, no one is more shocked than I am. I hope it passes. What will I do in my spare time? I’ll go for a piss, that’s a start.
No need to worry, I was just - (Turns to see it’s not Varys, but Jorah). Oh, I thought you were someone else. Shows almost over. I'm sure the girls inside will be happy to oblige.
You made some kind of mistake. Why don't you tell me what you think you are doing and -
Thank you. (After a long pause). Who are you?
Do you have wine?
I can't sleep without wine.
You're going the wrong way. My sister's in Westeros. Westeros is west! We're heading east.
You said you were taking me to the Queen.
(Chuckles). What a waste of a good kidnapping. So happens I was heading there myself!

Gold and glory. Oh, and hate. If you've ever met my sister, you'd understand. So now that it's clear we're on the same side? (Holds out his hands expectantly. Jorah makes no move to respond). A high born knight from the North of Westeros, down on his luck in Essos. Dragon epaulettes? Bear sigil breast plate. You're Jorah Mormont. I have to ask how, exactly, were you serving your Queen in a whore house, half a world away? Is it possible, that you were running? Why would you be running? And why would she have sent you away? Oh, wait! You were spying on her, weren't you? It's all coming back to me! I was drunk through most of the Small Council meetings, but it's all coming back. You passed notes to Varys's little birds. She found out, didn't she? Found out, and exiled you. (Jorah looks downtrodden). And now you hope to win back her favor with a gift. A risky scheme. One might even say, desperate. Do you think Daenerys would execute me, and pardon you? I'd say the reverse is just as likely.

Don't worry. I'll be fine. Nothing broken, I don't think. Where are we now? Not the Rhoyne. (No response). Long, sullen silences and an occasional punch in the face. The Mormont way. Let's start over. I apologize for before. My mouth sometimes runs away from me. This doesn't have to be an unpleasant trip. We're going to be spending a lot of time together on the way to Meereen.
What would make our time together truly enjoyable would be some wine.
I am a person who drinks. People who drink need to keep drinking. Otherwise, they're notâ€¦
I know where we are. You're taking us through Valyria.
Have you sailed this route before?
You're going to bring Daenerys a souvenir from her ancestral homeland in case I'm not enough?
You know what they say. The Doom still rules Valyria. What about the demons and the flames? Aren't you afraid of the Doom?
Oh.
The Smoking Sea. How many centuries before we learn how to build cities like this again? Thousands of years the Valyrians were the best in the world at almost everything. And then -

And then they weren't. "They held each other close and turned their backs upon the end. The hills that split asunder and the black that ate the skies; The flames that shot so high and hot that even dragons burned; Would never be the final sights that fell upon their eyes. A fly upon a wall, the waves the sea wind whipped and churned -"
I would clap.
I suppose this is it, then. This is what remains.
What was that?
Mormont, cut me free! (Jorah falls into the water). Mormont!
Mormont! Mormont!
(Shakes his head). You? (Jorah shakes his head). I've seen greyscale before, but nothing like that.

It'd be kinder to put daggers in their hearts and be done with it. (Jorah spits). Thank you for saving me. Of course, I wouldn't have needed saving if you hadn't kidnapped me in the first place. (Jorah gets up). So what now?
Without luck?
That's the best idea you've had all day.
So, those villages we were supposed to find. We can’t live on berries and roots.
You’re not hungry?
You’re an awful travelling companion, do you know that? Possibly the least charming man I have ever met.
We are travelling together. In each other’s company. Therefore…
I sailed from King’s Landing to Pentos in a crate. Without ever saying a word.
Never occurred to you to ask why until now? You never wondered why Tyrion Lannister decided to visit a brothel in Volantis.
I killed my father. He wanted to execute me for a crime I didn’t commit. And he was fucking the woman I loved.
As miserable as you are, Mormont, at least your father was a good man.

I met him. I visited the Wall. When I asked him about his men he knew all the stories, every one of them. He actually cared about the people in his command. How did they put it in the Watch? “We shall never see his like again.”
You didn’t know. I’m sorry. I am.
I only know what I heard
He was leading an expedition beyond the wall. There was a mutiny. He was murdered by his own men.
Why Daenerys? Why is she worth all this? As I recall, the Mormonts fought against the Targaryens during Robert’s Rebellion.
I believe in many things.
No.
No.
Doesn’t mean she’s going to be a great queen.
The Targaryens are famously insane. What if she conquers the world? Then what? 1,000 years of peace and prosperity?

We? Alright, let’s assume your dreams come true. She’s ecstatic when you bring her this enemy dwarf. She hacks off my head and restores your position. You command her army, sail to Westeros, defeat all your enemies, then watch as she climbs those steps and sits on the Iron Throne. Hurrah, long live the Queen. Then what?
So a woman who has not spent a single day of her adult life in Westeros becomes the ruler of Westeros? That’s justice?
Why, because her father who burned living men for amusement was the king?
Why is it anchored?
Wait, wait! Wait, wait, wait, let’s discuss this!
Wait, wait, wait, wait! You can’t just hand a dried cock to a merchant and expect him to pay for it. He has to know it came from a dwarf. And how could he know unless he sees the dwarf?
Guess again.
The fighting puts in Mereen! You’re in luck then, you’re about to be rich. You are looking at one of the great warriors in the seven kingdoms.
(looks at Jorah) Him.
Sure, he’s a bit long in the tooth, a bit withered, been in the sun too long. We can all see that. But he is a veteran of 100 battles. They wrote songs about him!
He won the tournament at Lannisport, unseating Ser Jaime Lannister himself.
The Kingslayer!
Wait! You have to buy me as well.
We’re a team. I’m a great fighter, too.
Thank you my Lord. Thank you.
My Lord, if I may. I’ve heard Mereen’s become a free city. You might run into trouble if you try to fight slaves in the fighting pits. Now if you were to fight free men who were paid a wage…
What are you doing?
It’s true. He has.
I am the gift. It’s a pleasure to meet you, Your Grace. My name is Tyrion Lannister.
If only I were otherwise.

You want revenge against the Lannisters? I killed my mother Joanna Lannister the day I was born. I killed my father Tywin Lannister with a bow to the heart. I am the greatest Lannister killer of our time.
Into your service? Your Grace we have only just met. It’s too soon to know if you deserve my service.

When I was a young man I heard a story about a baby born during the worst storm in living memory. She had no wealth, no lands, no army, only a name and a handful of supporters, most of whom probably thought they could use that name to benefit themselves. They kept her alive, moving her from place to place, often hours ahead of the men who had been sent to kill her. She was eventually sold off to some warlord on the edge of the world and that appeared to be that. And then a few years later the most well informed person I knew told me that this girl without wealth, lands, or armies had somehow acquired all 3 in a very short span of time, along with three dragons. He thought she was our best, last chance to build a better world. I thought you were worth meeting at the very least.

Because you can not build a better world on your own. You have no one at your side who understands that land you want to rule. The strengths and the weaknesses of the houses that will either support or oppose you.

Killing and politics aren’t always the same thing. When I served as Hand of the King I did quite well with the latter considering the king in question preferred torturing animals to leading his people. I could do an even better job advising a ruler worth the name.
I know.

Whomever Ser Jorah was when he started informing on you, he is no longer that man. I can’t remember seeing the same man as devoted to anything as he is to serving you. He claims he would kill for you and die for you, and nothing I have witnessed gives me reason to doubt him. And yet he did betray you.
Did he have an opportunity to confess his betrayals?
And did he?

He worships you. He is in love with you, I think. But he did not trust you with the truth - an unpleasant truth, to be sure - but one of great significance to you. He did not trust that you would be wise enough to forgive him.

A ruler who kills those that are devoted to her is not a ruler that inspires devotion. And you’re going to need to inspire devotion, and lots of it, if you’re ever going to rule across the Narrow Sea. But you cannot have him by your side when you do.
Have you decided yet whether you’re going to have me killed?
I can see why you would think so. It’s what your father would have done.
My father? Who publicly sentenced me to death? I’d say his thoughts on having me killed were abundantly clear.
Some day if you decide not to execute me, I’ll tell you all about why I killed my father. And on that day, should it ever come, we’ll need more wine than this.
So here we sit, two terrible children of two terrible fathers.
I’ve heard stories.
To see if you were the right kind of terrible.
The kind that prevents your people from being even more so.

Yes, that was wise. And you agreed to marry someone you loathed for the greater good. Very impressive. My own sister married someone she loathed as well, though not by choice and certainly not for the greater good, Gods forbid. She ended up having him killed.
It’s not impossible that Varys was right about you after all.
Yes. He was the one who convinced me to come find you. He was my travelling companion before Ser Jorah seized that role for himself.
He did what he had to do to survive. He did a lot of other things that he didn’t have to do. I suspect he’s the main reason you weren’t slaughtered in your crib.
Yes, oddly. He might be the only person in the world that I trust. Besides my brother.
That’s the one.
Your queenly prerogative. I had given up on life until Varys convinced me you might be worth living for. You chop off my head? Well, my final days were interesting.
No? Banish me?
So if I’m not going to be murdered, and I’m not going to be banished...
Advise you on what?
The Iron Throne. Perhaps you should try wanting something else.

I’m not entirely joking. There’s more to the world than Westeros after all. How many hundreds of thousands of lives have you changed for the better here? Perhaps this is where you belong. Where you can do the most good.
And when you get back to your home, who supports you?

Let’s be generous and assume that’s going to happen. Here in Slaver’s Bay you had the support of the common people and only the common people. What was that like, ruling without the rich? House Targaryen is gone, not a single person who shares your blood is alive to support you. The Starks are gone as well, our two terrible fathers saw to that. The remaining Lannisters won’t back you, not ever. Stannis Baratheon won’t back you either, his entire claim to the Throne depends on the illegitimacy of yours. That leaves the Tyrells. Not impossible, but not enough.
It’s a beautiful dream. Stopping the wheel. You’re not the first person to have dreamt it.
The smaller man it is.
There’s always been more than enough death in the world for my taste. I can do without it in my leisure time.
It’s easy to confuse what is with what ought to be. Especially when what is has worked in your favor.
My father would have liked you.
Well said, you’re an eloquent man. Doesn’t mean you’re wrong. In my experience, eloquent men are right every bit as often as imbeciles.
You can end this.
You can!
Stay close!

6.text: We’re never going to fix what’s wrong with this city from the top of an 800-foot pyramid.
We’ll be fine. We’re dressed like common merchants.
You’ve spent a lot of time studying the way rich people walk?
It’s a good thing you’re not a boy anymore...because you have no cock.
I know what mhysa means.
Hard to know. Our queen is not as popular in Meereen as she used to be.

Very possibly. Daenerys Targaryen took away their most valuable property, told them human beings weren’t even property to begin with. You can see why they’re unhappy. Of course, it could also be the freed men.
Many of the former slaves feel that Daenerys has abandoned them.
It’s a problem.
Fear has brought Meereen to a standstill. Whoever you are, wherever you go, someone in this city wants to murder you. We can’t fight an enemy we don’t know.
And have you started looking for that someone?
Well, we won’t be sailing to Westeros anytime soon.
How did he take it?

I know it was hard for you. You turned away a man who truly loves you because he would have been a liability in the Seven Kingdoms. That’s the kind of self-sacrifice that makes for a good ruler, if it’s any consolation.
No, I suppose not. I’m terrible at consoling.

All right, how about the fact that this is actually happening? You have your armies, you have your ships, you have your dragons. Everything you’ve ever wanted since you were old enough to want anything. It’s all yours for the taking. Are you afraid?
Good. You’re in the great game now. And the great game’s terrifying. The only people who aren’t afraid of failure are madmen like your father.
He wasn’t the first to love you and he won’t be the last.

For what it’s worth, I’ve been a cynic for as long as I can remember. Everyone’s always asking me to believe in things-- family, gods, kings, myself. It was often tempting until I saw where belief got people. So I said no, thank you to belief. And yet here I am.
I believe in you. It’s embarrassing, really. I’d swear you my sword, but I don’t actually own a sword.
It’s yours. Now and always.
If I lost my cock, I’d drink all the time.
Meaning no offense. He makes dwarf jokes, I make eunuch jokes.
You think them.
Surely there’s some good news lurking somewhere.
Perhaps they can tell us their secret.
What about the dragons? We have two of them here beneath the pyramid.
Daenerys is the dragon queen. Can’t very well let the dragons starve, that’s obvious.
Dragons do not do well in captivity.
That’s what I do. I drink and I know things.

The dragons Aegon used to conquer Westeros ranged over hundreds of miles. Then Daenerys’s ancestors started chaining them up in pens. A few generations later, the last dragons were no larger than cats. They must be unchained or they’ll waste away. Missandei, how many times were you in the company of these dragons?
And did they ever harm you?
Dragons are intelligent. More intelligent than men according to some maesters. They have affection for their friends and fury for their enemies. I am their friend.
They will. It’s time they had their supper.
I’m friends with your mother. I’m here to help. Don’t eat the help.
When I was a child an uncle asked what gift I wanted for my name day. I begged him for one of you. “It wouldn’t even have to be a big dragon,” I told him. “It could be little, like me.”
Everyone laughed like it was the funniest thing they had ever heard. Then my father told me the last dragon had died a century ago. I cried myself to sleep that night.
But here you are.
Next time I have an idea like that, punch me in the face.
What should we do while we wait? To pass the time, what should we do? What should we talk about?
You two, you spend a great deal of time together. What would you be talking about if I weren’t here?
That’s good. That’s very good.
But that’s a report. I was thinking more of a conversation. A wise man once said the truth history of the world is the history of great conversation in elegant rooms.
Me. Just now. All right, no conversations. Let’s play a game.
You don’t play games, either one of you, ever?
There, that’s a start.
Oh no, no, no. Not that, of course not that. Innocent games, fun games, drinking games.
Until you do.

Alright. No drinking. We can play without drinking. It’s a wonderful game. I invented it. Here’s how it works. I make a statement about your past. If I’m wrong, I drink. And if I’m right -- Maybe we can’t play without drinking.
Oh, you took your time.
You see? You don’t even have to worry about the local rebellion. We only have to worry about the three rich foreign cities paying for it.
If the Unsullied march off to reconquer Asatapor and Yunkai, who remain to defend the free people of Meereen?
You may be right.
Possibly.
It’s a conversation.
Tell me, can the little birds get a message to the good Masters of Astapor, the wise Masters of Yunkai, the benevolent enslavers of Volantis?
I did. As a clever man once told me, “We make peace with our enemies, not our friends.”
Yes, that’s the military approach. And how has that worked here in Meereen? I represent the diplomatic approach.
Long enough to know.
And now you speak for the Good Masters of Astapor.Here’s to reversals of fortune.
Let’s make this simple, shall we? Tell me what you want.
Queen Daenerys won’t stay in Meereen forever. Her path takes her westward.
Friends, friends, friends, please.
There have always been those with wealth and power and those with nothing. That is the way of the world. I’m not here to change the way of the world.

You don’t need slaves to make money. There haven’t been slaves in Westeros for hundreds of years and I grew up richer than any of you. But our queen recognizes that she erred by abolishing slavery without providing a new system to replace it. So here is the queen’s proposal. Slavery will never return to Meereen but she will give the other cities of Slaver’s Bay time to adjust to the new order.
Instead of abolishing slavery overnight, we will give you seven years to end the practice.
Slaveholders will be compensated for their losses, of course, at fair prices. In exchange, you will cut off your support for the Sons of the Harpy.
Fine, fine, but you will cut it off all the same. I do hope you accept, my friends. You will not receive a better offer.
Let us sail on the tide of freedom instead of being drowned by it. And as a parting gift to our honored guests…
Give freedom a chance. See if it doesn’t taste every bit as good as what came before.
Excellent.
I did.
I imagine this room was built so the rulers could intimidate the ruled.
But I am not your ruler. I’m not the Breaker of Chains. I’m not the Unburnt. And I am certainly not the Mother of Dragons.
Because our queen chose me as her advisor. Until she returns from her travels --
Soon. You have my word.
And that is exactly why Grey Worm took part in these negotiations. As commander of the Unsullied, he knows hot to defeat the slavers and he knows when it is time to make peace.
We offered terms.
Those men respect you.
As do I.
I am not betraying her work. I am trying to save her city.
For a short time.
You’re right. Slavery is a horror that should be ended at once. War is a horror that should be ended at once. I can’t do both today.
I don’t trust the Masters. I trust their self-interest. They’re trustworthy if they’re convinced that working with me is in their self-interest.
They look at me and they see a misshapen little beast. Their contempt is their weakness. They’ll underestimate us every time and we will use that to our advantage.
It’s not enough.

It’s not enough for Meereen to have peace. They need to know Daenerys is responsible for it. The Sons of the Harpy have a good story. Resist the foreign invaders. Our queen has an even better story. Mother of Dragons, Breaker of Chains and...all that.
Yes, but do they know who brought them security? Who brought about an end to the violence? We need someone the people trust, someone they know who cannot be bought or influenced.
Who said anything about “him”?
That’s about the extent of my Valyrian.
Thank you for travelling all this way. I know from personal experience how uncomfortable the journey can be.
The truth is we need your help. We had hoped that we could somehow persuade you to --
Yes.
She did indeed.
Ideally we’d avoid purifying too many nonbelievers. The Mother of Dragons has followers of many different faiths.
I’d settle for obeyed.
That sounds most excellent --
We’d be most grateful for any support you could provide the queen.
My friend has a healthy skepticism of religion, but we are all loyal supporters of the queen.
I’d call that a successful gambit.
Look around. The city has come back to life.
I did and it worked.
Spoken like a man who has never had to shave.
I’m going to miss you.
I hope you’re right about this expedition of yours.
Most of all, we need our queen.
Varys.
The most famous dwarf in the world.
I am happy. You should both be as well. Not so long ago, this city was ready to devour itself.
Now it’s like a man reborn.
Why don’t you drink? Why don’t either of you ever drink?
Why not?
And who made these rules? Your former masters?
Those miserable old shits didn’t want you to be human. Have a drink with me.
That’s how you know it’s working.
Here’s to our queen. Anyone not drinking is disrespecting our queen.
To Daenerys Stormborn, Mother of Dragons, Breaker of Chains, long may she reign.
Do you like it?
Yes, yes. Fermentation. One day, after our queen has taken the Seven Kingdoms...I’d like to have my own vineyard. Make my own wine. The Imp’s Delight. Only my close friends could drink it.
Tell me a joke, Missandei of Naath.
Grey worm?
Right. Three lords walk into a tavern- - a Stark, a Martell, and a Lannister. They order ale...

...but when the barkeep brings them over, each of them finds a fly in his cup. The Lannister, outraged, shoves the cup aside and demands another. The Martell plucks the fly out and swallows it whole. The Stark reaches into his cup, pulls out the fly and shouts, “Spit it out, you see shit. Spit it out.”
It’s funnier in Westeros.
Yes.
A story that’s supposed to make you laugh, ideally. Not at the moment, perhaps.
Missandei, do you like the wine?
Tell a joke.
You lied to us.
I once walked into a brothel with a honeycomb and a jackass. The madam says- -
I was wrong. I admit it.
The Unsullied could mount a defense off the beachhead. If the slavers’ forces- -
And I have acknowledged that. I’m trying- -
All right, what should the army do?
And then?
Despite appearances, I think you’ll find the city’s on the rise.
Perhaps we should take shelter.
Meereen is strong. Commerce has returned to the markets. The people are behind you.

Well, not all the people, of course. No ruler that ever lived had the support of all the people. But the rebirth of Meereen is the cause of this violence. The Masters cannot let Meereen succeed. Because if Meereen succeeds, a city without slavery, a city without Masters…
...it proves that no one needs a Master.
Do we have a plan?
You once told me you knew what your father was. Did you know his plans for King’s Landing when the Lannister armies were at his gates?

Probably not. Well, he told my brother and Jaime told me. He had caches of wildfire hidden under the Red Keep, the Guildhalls, the Sept of Baelor, all the major thoroughfares. He would have burned every one of his citizens. The loyal ones and the trators. Every man, woman, and child. That’s why Jaime killed him.
You’re talking about destroying cities. It’s not entirely different. I’d like to suggest an alternate approach.
We are here to discuss terms of surrender, not to trade insults.

Thank you for the armada. Our queen does love ships. Now, last time we spoke, we made a pact. You violated that pact. You declared war upon us. Though our queen does have a forgiving nature, this cannot be forgiven.
It always seems a bit abstract, doesn’t it, other people dying?

Tell your people what happened here. Tell them you live by the grace of Her Majesty. When they come forward with notions of retribution or ideas about returning the slave cities to their former glory, remind the what happened when Daenerys Stormborn and her dragons came to Meereen.

Last time we saw each other was at Winterfell, yes? You were making jokes about my height, I seem to recall. Everyone who makes a joke about a dwarf’s height thinks he’s the only person ever to make a joke about a dwarf’s height. “The height of nobility,” “a man of your stature,” “someone to look up to.” You’re all making the same five or six jokes.
It was. And how have things been going for you since then? Not so well, I gather. Can’t imagine you would have murdered the Stark boys if things had been going well.
Doesn’t seem like it. He’s still alive. It was complicated for you, I’m sure, growing up at Winterfell. Never quite knowing who you were. But then, we all live complicated lives, don’t we?
We can agree upon that at least.
With the former Masters’ fleet, possibly. Barely. There are more than 100 ships in the Iron Fleet.
The Seven Kingdoms.
What if everyone starts demanding their independence?

7.text: On a night like this, you came into the world.
We won't stay on Dragonstone for long.
Conquering Westeros would be easy for you. But you're not here to be queen of the ashes.

We can take the Seven Kingdoms without turning it into a slaughterhouse. If the great houses support your claim against Cersei, the game is won. With the Tyrell army and the Dornish on our side, we have powerful allies in the south.
Your Grace, when I was ready to drink myself into a small coffin, Lord Varys told me about a queen in the east who--
Lord Varys has proven himself a loyal servant.
Doesn't really roll off the tongue, does it?
Jon Snow? Ned Stark's bastard?
I traveled with him to the Wall when he joined the Night's Watch.
I can't speak to prophecies or visions in the flames, but I like Jon Snow and I trusted him, and I am an excellent judge of character.
If he does rule the north, he would make a valuable ally. The Lannisters executed his father and conspired to murder his brother. Jon Snow has even more reason to hate Cersei than you do.
If we turn the dragons loose, tens of thousands will die in the firestorms.
I know how you wage war. We don't poison little girls here. Myrcella was innocent.
But we won't use Dothraki and Unsullied.
Cersei will try to rally the lords of Westeros by appealing to their loyalty, their love for their country. If we besiege the city with foreigners, we prove her point. Our army should be Westerosi.
You are.
Lady Greyjoy will escort you home to Sunspear and her Iron Fleet will ferry the Dornish army back up to King's Landing.
The Dornish will lay siege to the capital alongside the Tyrell army. Two great kingdoms united against Cersei.

The unsullied will have another objective. For decades House Lannister has been the true power in Westeros. And the seat of that power is Casterly Rock. Grey Worm and the Unsullied will sail for the Rock and take it.
The bastard of Winterfell.
I believe we last saw each other on top of the wall.
It's been a long road. But we're both still here.
I'm Tyrion Lannister.
Ah, the Onion Knight. We fought on opposite sides at the Battle of Blackwater Bay.
Missandei is the queen's most trusted advisor.
And Sansa, I hear she's alive and well.
Does she miss me terribly?
A sham marriage and unconsummated.
Well, it was. It wasn't. Anyway, she's much smarter than she lets on.
Good. At some point I want to hear how a Knight's Watch recruit became King in the North.
A long and bloody tale. To be honest, I was drunk for most of it.
Of course they do. If I was your hand I would have advised against it. General rule of thumb, Stark men don't fare well when they travel south.
I'd say you get used to them, but you never really do.
Come. Their mother is waiting for you.
Your Grace, this is Ser Davos Seaworth.
Forever.
Almost.
I do.
I believe he's calling all of us children. Figure of speech.
The Army of the Dead?
No, I don't think you're either of those things.
The war against my sister has already begun. You can't expect us to halt hostilities and join you in fighting --
-- whatever you saw beyond the wall.
If it doesn't matter you might as well kneel.
Swear your allegiance to Queen Daenerys. Help her to defeat my sister and together our armies will protect the north.
It takes no time to bend the knee. Pledge your sword to her cause.

I came out here to brood over my failure to predict the Greyjoy attack. You're making it difficult. You look a lot better brooding than I do. You make me feel like I'm failing at brooding over failing.
I wouldn't say you're a prisoner on this island. You're free to walk the castle, the beaches, to go wherever you want.
I wouldn't say we took your ship.
Why don't you figure out what to do about my missing fleet and murdered allies, and I'll figure out what to do about your walking dead men.
I do actually.
It was all nonsense. Everybody knew it. But then Mormont saw them and you saw them, and I trust the eyes of an honest man more than I trust what everybody knows.
Good question.
People's minds aren't made for problems that large. White Walkers, the Night King, Army of the Dead, it's almost a relief to confront a familiar monster like my sister.
It seems unlikely that you became King in the North by giving up that easily.

Children are not their fathers, luckily for all of us. And sometimes there's more to foreign invaders than northern fools that meets the eye. Daenerys could have sailed for Westeros long ago but she didn't. Instead she stayed where she was and saved many people from horrible fates some of whom are on this island with us right now. While you're our guest here you might consider asking them what they think of the Mad King's daughter. She protects people from monsters, just as you do. That's why she came here. And she's not about to head north to fight an enemy she's never seen on a word of a man she doesn't know after a single meeting. That's not a reasonable thing to ask.
So do you have anything reasonable to ask?
Maybe you are a northern fool. I'm asking if there's something I can do to help you.
Yes. Volcanic glass, obsidian. He says you have a tremendous amount of it here.
Which is why I was speaking to Jon Snow, a potential ally.
Apparently it can be turned into weapons that kill White Walkers and their foot soldiers, or stop them, destroy them. I'm unsure of the nomenclature.
I'd very much like to believe that Jon Snow is wrong, but a wise man once said that you should never believe a thing simply because you want to believe it.
I don't remember.

I would never do that...to you. The reason I believe Jon Snow is because he's here. All of his advisors would have told him not to come. I would have told him not to come, yet he's here anyway. You don't have to believe him. Let him mine the Dragonglass. If he's wrong it's worthless. You didn't even know it was here. It's nothing to you. Give him something by giving him nothing. Take a step toward a more productive relationship with a possible ally. Keep him occupied while we focus on the task at hand. Casterly Rock.
You must allow them their flights of fancy. It's dreary in the north.
But you'll have to go yourself. Euron's ships could be anywhere or in more than one place. You'd be flying around the open seas alone for who knows how long.
It's too great a risk. You're too important.
Yes. Cersei believes my sole purpose in life is to destroy House Lannister. She will be ready.
No one has ever taken the rock.
The Lannister army is still the army my father built. Well trained and well provisioned. 10,000 men at least. They will see us coming.
They will be ready.
The gates of Casterly Rock are impregnable.
The fight up the walls will be hard. We'll be at a disadvantage. Many men will die.

Interesting thing about my father. He built our house up from near ruin. He built our army. He built Casterly Rock as we know it, but he didn't build the sewers. That was beneath him. So he gave the job to the lowest person he could find. Me. He was right. I was low. The company I kept low, women mostly. They weren't welcome at the Rock. Father disapproved of that sort of behavior. I couldn't walk them through the front gates. I couldn't have them in my chambers. So in the process of building the sewers I threw in something for myself.
It was a passage that began by the sea and ended beneath one of the main guard towers.
No better place for low pursuits. Casterly Rock, the impregnable fortress.
As a good friend of mine once said, "give me 10 good men and I'll impregnate the bitch."
And so it begins. They will face the bulk of the Lannister forces. They will be outnumbered. They will have less armor and fewer weapons.

But as my sister's armies fights for her, the Unsullied will be fighting for something greater. They will be fighting for freedom and the person who gave it to them. They will be fighting for you. And that is why they will triump.
We took Casterly Rock.
We still have the largest army.
Call Grey Worm and the Unsullied back. We still have enough ships to carry the Dothraki to the mainland. Commit to the blockade of King's Landing. We have a plan. It's still the right plan.
If I've underestimated our enemies --
We've discussed this.
A smart one.
Flee, you idiot!
You fucking idiot.
My sister, she wasn't your queen until recently though, was she, until she murdered your rightful queen and destroyed House Tyrell for all time. So it appears your allegiances are somewhat flexible.
Perhaps he could take the black, Your Grace. Whatever else he is, he is a true soldier. He would be invaluable at the Wall.
You are the future of your house. This war has already wiped one great house from the world. Don't let it happen again. Bend the knee.
Your Grace, nothing strips bold notions from a man's head like a few weeks in a dark cell.
Your Grace, if you begin beheading entire families --
Your Grace --
All rulers demand that people bend the knee. It's why they're rulers. She gave Tarley a choice. A man who had taken up arms against her. What else could she do?
I am her hand, not her head. I can't make her decisions for her.
Daenerys is not her father.
Who is that for?
Did you read it?
What's it say?
Perhaps not. Cersei thinks the Army of the Dead is nothing but a story made up by wet nurses to frighten children. What if we prove her wrong?
So bring the dead to her.
We don't have to bring the whole army. Only one soldier.
Bring one of these things down to King's Landing and show her the truth.
The only person she listens to is Jaime. He may listen to me.
Last time I was here I killed my father with a crossbow.
You're not staying here?
What if someone takes the boat?
I needed to see you and I knew you'd never agree to meet.

You made me look like a complete fool. I thought I'd surprise you by hitting Casterly Rock, but you were three steps ahead of me. You abandoned the family home. Completely unsentimental. Father would have been proud.
Listen to me --
It would take you awhile with a sparring sword.

He was going to execute me. He knew I was innocent. He didn't hate me because of anything I did, he hated me because of what I am. The little monster sent to punish him. Do you think I wanted to be born this way? Did he think I chose --
Daenerys will win this war. You're a military man. You must know there is no way around it. Daenerys is not her father. She's even willing to suspend hostilities if Cersei agrees to certain terms.
I -- I don't. Daenerys doesn't. Not right now anyway. She has a more important request.
Fish hook. Some men you just can't teach.
He'll do.
You may not believe it, but I've missed you Mormont. Nobody glowers quite like you. Not even Grey Worm.
This is the coin the slaver gave me when I suggested he free us and pay us. Remember?
Take it with you. You'll bring it back. Our queen needs you.
I honestly don't.
Oh. I've been heroic on occasion.
I once charged through the mud gate of King's Landing.
It's interesting these heroes you name. Drogo, Jorah, Dario, even this Jon Snow, they all fell in love with you.
Oh, my mistake. I suppose he stares at you longingly because he's hopeful for a successful military alliance.
A million, give or take.
There's more work in the city. And the brothels are far superior.

I imagine it was a sad joke at the end. An entire arena for a few sickly creatures smaller than dogs. But in the beginning, when it was home to Balerion the Dread, it must have been the most dangerous place in the world.
A pleasant surprise in an unpleasant situation.
Supporting the enemy, no less.
Cersei will anyway.
(Shakes his head.)
Here we are the heroes of Blackwater Bay. Strange place for a reunion.
I don't think I'm anyone's lord anymore, Podrick. Save the titles for Ser Bronn of the Blackwater.
You've been thinking about our new queen.
Are you? Helping me to arrange this meeting wasn't exactly looking after yourself, was it? You put yourself at risk.
It's good to see you again.
You might.
And some Clegane cunt to help them see it through.
She'll be here soon.
No.
We are all facing a unique
I think we ought to begin with larger concerns.
Do you remember when we discussed dwarf jokes? His wasn't even good. He explained it at the end. Never explain. It always ruins it.

We are a group of people who do not like one another, as this recent demonstration has shown. We have suffered at each other's hands. We have lost people we love at each other's hands. If all we wanted was more of the same, there would be no need for this gathering. We are entirely capable of waging war against each other without meeting face-to-face.
We all know that will never happen.
There is no conversation that will erase the last 50 years. We have something to show you.
I'm pleased you bent the knee to our queen
That is indeed a problem. The more immediate problem is that we're fucked.
Only one. Everyone stays here, and I go and talk to my sister.
I don't want Cersei to murder me either. I could have stayed in my cell and saved a great deal of trouble.
She'll definitely murder you. I go see my sister.
You spoke with her?
I'm about to step into a room with the most murderous woman in the world who's already tried to kill me twice, that I know of. Who's an idiot?
A foreign whore you can't abduct, beat, or intimidate. That must be difficult for you.
I didn't know about that.
Cersei, I didn't know.

I am the one preventing that from happening. Daenerys didn't want to debate and negotiate. She didn't want to bring you words. She wanted to bring you fire and blood until I advised her otherwise. I don't want to destroy our family. I never have.
After he sentenced me to death for a crime I didn't commit, yes, I killed him. Hate me for it if you want. I hate myself for it in spite of what he was, in spite of what he did to me.
I have never been more sorry about anything.
(starts)
All right. You love your family, and I have destroyed it. I will always be a threat. So put an end to me.
If it weren't for me, you'd have a motherIf it weren't for me, you'd have a father.
I am more sorry about the children than you could ever know.
I don't care. I loved them. You know I did. You know it in your heart if there's anything left of it.
