You've got a big mouth, girl, and too many teeth.
Lady Reed here's got a stick so far up her ass, it's a wonder her feet touch the ground.
Me? It's my fault? First time I met her, she put a knife to my throat.
I said so, didn't I?
You're a good little hunter.
Don't push me.
What's he going on about? And how come he always gets to sit and chat while we do all the work?
What are you telling him?
It's not all right. You think I can't hear you every day? Filling his head with black magic. Talking about visions and three-eyed ravens and worse.
He can speak for himself.
So what do you talk about?
Go on, then. Tell us what it means.
I don't want you talking to him anymore. Until we get to your brother at Castle Black.
What did you say?
Oh, no. I'm not going back there. Your brother is at Castle Black. That's where we're going. Look at me.
You have a family. You need to go back to Castle Black so you can get back to them where you belong.

Is that what he's telling you? That it's all for a reason? All these bad things happened because the gods got big plans for you? I wish it were true, little lord. But the gods wouldn't spare a raven's cold shit for you or me or anyone.

You don't know. None of you know. None of you have been up there. I had a man once. A good man. Bruni, his name was. I was his and he was mine. But one night Bruni disappears. People said he left me, but I knew him. He'd never leave me. Not for long.

I knew he'd come back. And he did. He came in through the back of the hut. Only it wasn't Bruni. Not really. His skin was pale like a dead man's. His eyes bluer than clear sky. He came at me, grabbed me by the neck and squeezed so hard I could feel the life slipping out of me. I don't know how I got the knife. When I did, I stuck it deep into his heart. And he hardly seemed to notice. I had to burn our hut down with him inside. I didn't ask the gods what it meant. I didn't need to. I already knew. It meant the North was no place for men to be. Not anymore. I promised your maester I'd get you to Castle Black and no further.
Where are we?
We can drink some blood while we wait. I don’t need much.
Got in a boat and rowed past the Bay of Seals.
Some climb straight up the ice.
It’s just thunder, sweet giant.
[To BRAN and RICKON] Where’s Shaggydog and Summer?
You need to keep quiet.
That’s a horse dying.
They’re long gone.
He’ll be heading back to Castle Black then. That’s where we should go.
I already told you. I’m not going north of the Wall.
Listen to me, little lord.
You Southerners build your big castles and you never move. You’re easy to find.
Shhh. [She grabs RICKON by the waist and sits him on her lap] Come here, little soldier. You and me, we’re gonna have some adventures.

Your family took me in and was good to me when they had no cause to be. [To RICKON] Shhh. We’ll be fine, you and me. The Umbers are great warriors. Even I heard about them growing up. They’ll teach you how to swing a sword.
I learned to walk in darkness.
Say your good-byes, little man.
[Looks at the Reeds] Keep this one safe. [MEERA gives a slight nod] He means the world to me.

6.text: A lord?
The flayed man.
You eat them after?
Then I’ve seen worse.
Aye. They put me in chains and put a sword at my throat, so I’ve served them.
He'd fetch a good price to the right buyer. I served his family a long time. Didn’t get no wages. Way I see it, I’m owed.
I can give you what you want.
Same thing men always want. And when they really want it, they give it a bath first.
That so?

3.text: Let's find a place to sleep.
I always quite liked the horrible stories.
Where are you going?
Shush.
Doesn't matter.
How did you get through the Wall?
There's nowhere safe any longer. You know that.
You saw the white walkers and the army of the dead.
The Night's Watch can't stop them. The kings of Westeros and all their armies can't stop them.
Dragonglass.
You can't kill it, you know.
Because the raven is you.
I'm unarmed.
My sister carries the weapons.
You must be Summer.
I'm Jojen Reed. This is my sister Meera. We've come a long way to find you, Brandon. And we have much farther to go.
You can get inside his head, see through his eyes.
That's how it begins until you learn to control it. You're a warg.
A three-eyed raven?
We saw him together. You haven't forgotten?
No, the raven is something different, something deeper. The raven brings the sight.
Or things that happened long before you were born or things that are happening right now thousands of miles away.
You didn't dream it. You saw it. So did I.
(Nods.) When I told my father about your father for the first time in my life, I saw him cry.
Yeah.
Your father told you about the rebellion? Mine never did. But I saw that, too.
Only one thing that matters-you.
You have to go after him.
You know how.
I saw Jon Snow.
He was on the wrong side of the Wall surrounded by enemies.
That's where we are.
I don't fill his head with anything.
What's happening to him and what that means.
It's not like that. I wish I could tell him all the answers. It would be much easier.
We're not going to Castle Black.
I told you already. Jon Snow isn't there. Bran needs to find the raven beyond the Wall.
Doesn’t seem to be supporting anyone at the moment.
There’s a storm coming.
Nineteen castles guard the Wall. Only three are still manned.
One of those abandoned fortresses will give us a way through.
Just one?
Wildlings.
Shhh, quiet, Hodor.
[To BRAN] Make him shut up. If they hear us…
They’re gonna hear us.
[Looks at BRAN] The wolves are out there.
You’re a warg, Bran. It’s in your blood.
You just did, with him.
A wolf is nothing compared to that.
Do it. They’ll find us if you don’t.
Of course you can. North of the Wall there are wildlings who can control all sorts of animals. But you did a lot more than that. You got inside Hodor’s mind.
No one can do that. Anywhere.

4.text: We'll rest with the three-eyed raven.
We're already here.
Bran! Save yourself, now!
Summer was eating. Your body can't live on the food your wolf consumes. Spending too much time in Summer's skin is dangerous. You're not a direwolf, Bran.
Must be glorious, though. To run, to leap, to hunt. To be whole. I know that's tempting, but if you're trapped in Summer for too long, you'll forget what it was to be human.
It's coming.
Bran. Bran.
It doesn't matter.
You mustn't let anything stop you.
No. You're not here. You're far from here.
At the hill. A great weirwood tree.
Meera and I, even Hodor, we're only here to guide you. He's waiting for you. We have to find it. You have to make it.
This... this isn't the end. Not for you. Not yet.
You'll know.
Stop. What are you doing?
If you let my sister go, I can help you.
I can.
I have the sight. I can see things.
Things that haven't happened yet.
No.
I saw you die tonight. I saw your body burn. I saw the snow fall and bury your bones.
If he sees you, he won't let you go north.
And wants to protect you. He'll take you back to Castle Black.
You have to decide. Do you want to find the three-eyed raven?

1.text: l'll have peace on those terms. They can keep their Red Castle and their iron chair too. (bows to Robb and extends him his sword) The King in the North!

2.text: Ser Alton's pen is occupied, Your Grace. The prisoners from the Yellow Fork.
Does he need to lie down?
Torrhen.
Get back! I want his head! Any man who stands between a father and his vengeance asks for death.
This monster killed my son.
I will have his head. And if you try and stop me
And where is our king now?
He has gone to the Crag to accept the surrender. Aye, gone to the Crag, but not to negotiate. He brought that foreign bitch with him.
Treason? How can it be treason to kill Lannisters?
When your son returns, I will demand this murderer's head.
Fathers who love their sons do. I will have his head.

I lost one son fighting by your son's side. I lost another to the Kingslayer, strangled with a chain. You commit treason because your children are prisoners? I would carve out my heart and offer it to the Father, if he would let my sons wake from their graves and step into a prison cell.
I don't want your grief. I want my vengeance. And you stole it from me.

3.text: 200 Northmen slaughtered like sheep.
Will it? They rot in the ground while their killer runs free.
We're at war. This march is a distraction.
Not murder, Your Grace. Vengeance.
Was strangled by the Kingslayer. They were his kin.
Tell your mother to look at them. She killed them as much as I.
It's treason to free your enemies. In war, you kill your enemies. Did your father not teach you that, boy?
Aye. Leave me to the king. He wants to give me a scolding before he sets me free. That's how he deals with treason. Our King in the North. Or should I call him the King Who Lost the North?
The blood of the First Men flows through my veins as much as yours, boy. I fought the Mad King for your father. I fought Joffrey for you. We are kin-- Stark and Karstark.
I don't want it to save me. I want it to haunt you to the end of your days.
Kill me and be cursed. You are no king of mine.

6.text: But if you have to fight, win.

1.text: I’m told he drinks all night.
We’ve brought up eight barrels of ale from the cellar. Perhaps we’ll find out.
Pardon, my lord, my lady. A rider in the night from your sister.
If this news is true, and the Lannisters conspire against the throne, who but you can protect the king?
The king rode for a month to ask Lord Stark’s help. He’s the only one he trusts. You swore the king an oath, my lord.
A different time. Different king.
Bran…
It's time we reviewed the accounts, my lady. You'll want to know how much this royal visit has cost us.
Poole went south with Lord Stark, my lady. We need a new steward, and there are several other appointments that require our immediate attention...
Very good, my Lord. My Lady.
The boy was always sure-footed before.
What, is there going to be a battle in the Godswood? Too easily words of war become acts of war. We don't know the truth yet. Lord Stark must be told of this.
He has no memory of that day.
The boy has lost the use of his legs.
Bran...
Lords?
And failed rebellions.
Good.
Hmm...
No. A common saying, but not their official motto.
We're still on their words.
You do know them. Think.
That's House Martell.
House Hornwood.
Those are Tully words... Your mother's. Are we playing a game?
You know it is.
Your mother had to leave Winterfell to protect the family.
Your mother sat by your bed for three weeks while you slept.
When you were born, I was the one who pulled you from your mother. I placed you in her arms. From that moment until the moment she dies, she will love you. Absolutely. Fiercely.
I still can't tell you, but she will be home soon.
No, I don't.
Sometimes I worry you're too smart for your own good.
And where is that written?
Hmm... If the saddle Lord Tyrion designed actually works, you could learn to shoot a bow from horseback.
Dothraki boys learn when they're four years old. Why shouldn't you?
Theon Greyjoy! The lady is our guest.
Are the two mutually exclusive in your experience?
Chances are I won't be nearby the next time that happens.
Why did you come here?
Why? What are you afraid of?
Owls and Shadowcats and...
The "things" you speak of-- they've been gone for thousands of years.
It is your sister's hand, but the Queen's words.
This is a royal command, My Lord.
All of them, My Lord?
They have.
Yeah.

2.text: Maintenance of a Holdfast generally falls to the lord of that Holdfast.
We can spare four masons for a week, My Lord. Will that be sufficient to repair your walls?
We didn't want him here all day, did we?
Nor did I. But listening to people you'd rather not listen to is one of your responsibilities as Lord of Winterfell. (Bran sighs). Lord Portan.
They want you to know you're surrounded.
They don't want you to sleep. They want to sap your spirit before
No.
You killed all the ravens.
Lord Stark went out of his way to make it your home.
Theon, listen to me. I serve Winterfell. Now Winterfell is yours. I'm bound by oath to serve you.
Run.
Five hundred Northmen wait outside the walls. You have 20 men. You can't win. Wait for nightfall and run.
Don't go home. Join the Night's Watch.
Once a man has taken the black, he's beyond reach of the law. All his past crimes are forgiven.
There are ways. Hidden passageways built so the Lords of Winterfell could escape. The road will be dangerous. But with a little luck...
The Night's Watch is an ancient, honorable order. You'll have opportunities there.
The opportunity to make amends for what you've done.
I've known you many years, Theon Greyjoy. You're not the man you're pretending to be. Not yet.
What is this? What are you doing?
Not everything. Not you. But they may come back. You have to go. Put on your warmest clothes. Pack as much food as you can carry and go north.
There are too many enemies in the south. Go to the Wall, to Jon. He'll look after you and let your mother know you're safe.

No more than I want to leave you. I pulled you into the world. Both of you. I've seen both your faces almost every day since. And for that, I consider myself very, very lucky. Go now with Hodor. Go on. I'll be right here.
Osha. You must protect them. You're the only one who can. You may have to protect them against your own kind.
Do it quickly.
Hodor. Rouse Bran, will you? It's time for his lessons.
That's exactly what they are, Bran, - stories.
Well, they may have done. But they're gone from the world, along with much else. These are dreams, Bran, nothing more.
What about all the dreams you had that didn't come true? Hmm? Right.

This link is made of Valyrian steel. Only one maester in 100 wears it on his chain. It signifies that I have studied the higher mysteries. And all who study these mysteries try their hand at spells. I was no different. I was young. And what boy doesn't secretly wish for hidden powers to lift him out of his dull life into a special one? But in the end, for all my efforts, I got no more out of it than a thousand boys before me. Come on.
All right. Maybe magic once was a mighty force in the world. But not anymore. The dragons are gone. The giants are dead. And the Children of the Forest forgotten.
Good.
Torrhen's Square is barely 40 leagues from here. How can the Lannisters strike so far north?
Do you need so many?
I am.
My lord.
I urge you not to make a hasty decision.
He is worth more to you alive than dead. The Starks will pay. Please, Theon, think what you do.
So far, hunting seems very similar to riding, my lord.
They're little boys.
Those boys are of far more value to you alive than dead.
Robb will have sent a force to retake Winterfell by now.
We could start the search fresh in the morning, my lord.
Theon, don't do this.
What are you doing? What have you done?
No!
You're right so far.
Must have been the farmer's boys.
They mustn't know. Bran would blame himself.

1.text: Lord Stark. My lady. A guardsman just rode in from the hills. They’ve captured a deserter from the Night’s Watch.
The law is law, my lady.
They don’t belong down here.
Should I gag him?
My Lady, this way.
I'll be fine, my Lady. There's no need to bloody yourself.
Summer snows, My Lady.
Jon.
We should go, my lady.
My lady!

2.text: Bran! Lord Stark. Torrhen's Square is under siege.
Might be a raiding party led by the mountain. Might be sellswords paid by Tywin Lannister.
Most of the fighting men are away with Robb, but I can gather 200 decent men.
Won't take long, my lord. Southerners don't do well up here.
It grieves me you've less honor than a back alley whore. You were raised here under this roof. These people are your people.
King Robb thought of you as a brother.
Aye, they died fighting a war your father started. Lord Stark raised you among his own sons.
If he were alive to see this
I should have put a sword in your belly instead of in your hand.
He who passes the sentence should swing the sword.
Coward.
Hush now, child. I'm off to see your father.
Gods help you, Theon Greyjoy. Now you are truly lost.

1.text: My lord! My lord! They found her. She's unharmed.
She's been taken directly before the King.
The Lannisters found her.
The Queen ordered them to bring her straight to him.
Yes, my Lord.
Ser Hugh? Ser Hugh!
I'm here on behalf of Lord Eddard Stark, the Hand of the king. I'm the captain of his guard.
No "ser." I'm not a knight.
He said he'd be glad to talk to the Hand himself. He's a knight, you see.
You shouldn't be out here, my Lord. There's no telling who has eyes where.
Find anything?
This is for the King from Lord Stark.
Three? Four?
Forgive me, my Lord...
We've met before, you know.
The siege of Pyke. We fought side by side one afternoon.
Aye. One of the Greyjoys nearly took my eye.
They like their bloodshed.
With his burning sword? I'll remember that till the day I die.
Theon? He's a good lad.
Can I leave this with you? The message from Lord Stark.
My Lord, Her Grace the Queen.
Pardon, my Lord. There's a Night's Watchman here begging a word. He says it's urgent.
Come along, my Lady. You heard your father.
Here in King's Landing? Fifty.
No fear on that count, little Lady.
Right away, my Lord. Lord Baelish is here for you.
Heward and Wyl.
My Lord.
Stay back, Ser! This is the Hand of the King!
If you threaten my Lord again...
I love the detail that you’ve managed to get in this corners. … Quite beautiful … the stitching …
Enough of that, young lady. Eat your food.
Arya, stop!
Enough!
Arya would rather act like a beast than a lady.
You've barely eaten a thing.

Someday your husband will sit there and you will sit by his side. And one day, before too long, you will present your son to the court. All the lords of Westeros will gather here to see the little prince...
Gods be good, you'll have boys and girls and plenty of them.
I wouldn't worry about that.
Yes, but it's highly unlikely.
If you only had girls, I suppose the throne would pass to Prince Joffrey's little brother.
Nobody could ever hate you.
Nonsense. Why would you say such a thing? That business with the wolves? I've told you a hundred times... A direwolf is not...
Do you remember your lessons? Who built the Iron Throne?
And who built the Red Keep?
And how many years did it take to build...
They were killed on the orders of King Aerys, yes.
Commonly known as the Mad King.
You should speak to your father about these matters.
You will find it in your heart to forgive your father.
Sansa dear, this is Lord Baelish. He's known...
Don't be rude!
You wear your hair like a real southern lady now.
It’s important to remember where you come from. I’m not sure your mother would like these new styles.
I’m aware of that.
Yes. I have hair.
Would you like to?
I come from a very small village in -
Sansa -
Now you are being rude.
My prince.
Your sister knew perfectly well we were to leave today.
Hush! Go back to your room.
Do as I told you. Run!

5.text: Confess. Confess.
Shame. Shame. Shame. (rings bell)
Confess.
Confess. I meant it.
Thirsty? Confess.
Confess.
Confess.

1.text: Don't listen to it. Crows are all liars. I know a story about a crow.
I know a story about a boy who hated stories. I could tell you about Ser Duncan the Tall. Those were always your favorites.

Oh, my sweet summer child. What do you know about fear? Fear is for the winter, when the snows fall a hundred feet deep. Fear is for the long night, when the sun hides for years and children are born and live and die all in darkness. That is the time for fear, my little Lord, when the White Walkers move through the woods. Thousands of years ago there came a night that lasted a generation. Kings froze to death in their castles, same as the shepherds in their huts. And women smothered their babies rather than see them starve, and wept and felt the tears freeze on their cheeks. So is this the sort of story that you like? In that darkness, the White Walkers came for the first time. They swept through cities and kingdoms, riding their dead horses, hunting with their packs of pale spiders big as hounds…
Only what the little Lord wants to hear.
The little Lord's been dreaming again.
Of course, your Grace.
A Tyroshi. Never learned the name.
Lance through the heart.
I was there that day. You were only a squire, 16 years old.
A good fighter, Toyne, but he lacked stamina.
No. I stood vigil for him myself last night. He had no one else.
Bad luck for him... Going against the Mountain.
All the knights draw straws, Lord Stark.
Life is strange. Not so many years ago we fought as enemies at the Trident.
You're too modest. I've seen you cut down a dozen great knights.
He was a fine man, your father. What the Mad King did to him was a terrible crime.
Perhaps Lord Arryn left him some money? I hear the King wants to joust today.
Robert tends to do what he wants.
I don’t believe so, your Grace.
He was reeling from the wine.
His squire, from the king's own skin.
King Robert's seal. Unbroken.
Those were the King's words.
Your Grace, I am yours to command.
Your Grace, the Kingsguard is a sworn brotherhood.
Your Grace...
The man who profaned his blade with the blood of the King he had sworn to defend!
A hall to die in and men to bury me.
Even now I could cut through the five of you like carving a cake!

3.text: The honor is mine, my queen.
King Robert is dead. I have been searching for you, Daenerys Stormborn, to ask your forgiveness. I was sworn to protect your family. I failed them.
They will come, Your Grace. When they're ready.
The Walk of Punishment is a warning, Your Grace.
To any slave who contemplates doing whatever these slaves did.
Leave this place, Your Grace. Leave tonight, I beg you.
We can find sellswords in Pentos and Myr.
Three.
(Shakes his head.)

When your brother Rhaegar led his army into battle at the Trident, men died for him because they believed in him, because they loved him, not because they'd been bought at a slaver's auction. I fought beside the last dragon on that day, Your Grace. I bled beside him.
I did, Your Grace. Finest man I ever met.
You will win the throne with dragons, not slaves, Your Grace.
Aegon Targaryen proved that.
Mm, you were first through the breach at Pyke?
Thoros of Myr. Bloody madman. Robert knighted you after the battle?
(laughs)
Robert would have laughed. He was a good man, a great warrior. And a terrible king. I burned away my years fighting for terrible kings.

Yes. And a man of honor keeps his vows, even if he's serving a drunk or a lunatic. Just once in my life before it's over, I want to know what it's like to serve with pride, to fight for someone I believe in. Do you believe in her?
Of course he wanted her dead. She's a Targaryen. The last Targaryen.
I didn't sit on the small council.
Traditionally, yes, but I killed a dozen of Robert's friends during his rebellion.
He didn't want advice on how to govern from a man who had fought for the Mad King. Can't say I minded much. I always hated the politics.
Mm-hmm.
She'll have good men around her to advise her, men with experience.
Forgive me, Ser Jorah, for what I'm about to say, but your reputation in Westeros has suffered over the years.
I don't know if your presence by her side will help our cause when we go home.
We both want her to rule. Am I wrong?
If we're truly her loyal servants, we will do whatever needs to be done, no matter the cost, no matter our pride.
The Yunkish train bed slaves, not soldiers. We can defeat them.
The Yunkish are a proud people. They will not bend.
Men who fight for gold have neither honor nor loyalty. They cannot be trusted.
2,000, Your Grace. Armored and mounted.
(nods)
Your Grace, allow me to present the captains of the Second Sons-- Mero of Braavos, Prendahl na Ghezn, and--
Under 2,000, Your Grace.
10,000 Unsullied.
Gladly, Your Grace.
We're not gonna sneak an army through a back gate.
Ser Jorah. You can use an extra sword.

4.text: Your Grace.
Gambling, Your Grace.
163, Your Grace. I'll tell our men to ride ahead and bury them. You don't need to see this.
The masters will take advantage of this situation. The men serving them will be slaves in all but name.
I believe he means to...
Ignore him, Your Grace. These are meaningless words.
Your Grace, I've won more single combats than any man alive.
Your Grace, may I have a word? The city is yours. All these people,they're your subjects now. Sometimes it is better to answer injustice with mercy.
And we have taken the Meereenese Navy, Your Grace.
93, Your Grace.
9,300, not counting sailors.

They've been fighting Joffrey's wars for years. They're tired, dispersed. And now their king is dead. 8,000 Unsullied, 2,000 Second Sons sailing into Blackwater Bay and storming the gates without warning.
The old houses will flock to our queen when she crosses the Narrow Sea.

5.text: Yes, your grace. They left it on the body.
It was only a matter of time, your grace. Conquerors are always met with resistance.
The Sons of the Harpy will hear that message.
I think you should exercise restraint, Your Grace.
For one thing, he may have valuable information.
How do you know that?

We do not know what this man did or didn't do. (to Daenerys) Give him a trial, at least. A fair trial. Show all of the citizens of Meereen that you are better than those who would depose. Teach them a better way.
Your Grace, a word, please, I beg you.
About your father. About the Mad King.
Your Grace, I served in his Kingsguard. I was at his side from the first. Your enemies did not lie.

When the people rose in revolt against him, your father set their towns and castles aflame. He murdered sons in front of their fathers. He burned men alive with Wildfire, and laughed as they screamed. And his efforts to stamp out dissent led to rebellion that killed every Targaryen except two.
No, Your Grace. Thank the gods. But the Mad King gave his enemies the justice he thought they deserved. And each time it made him feel powerful and right. Until the very end.
Your Grace.
I'll stand guard outside your door tonight, Your Grace.
I was thinking of all the times your brother made me go with him down from the Red Keep, into the streets of King's Landing.
He liked to walk among the people, he liked to sing to them.
Yes. Rhaegar would take a spot on the Hook or the Street of Seeds and then he'd sing. Just like all the other minstrels.
I made sure no one killed him. And I collected the money. (Daenerys looks surprised). Well he liked to see how much he could make.
He was very good. Viserys never told you?
Rhaegar never liked killing. He loved singing.
Well, one time, he gave it to the next minstrel down the street. One time, he gave it to an orphanage in Flea Bottom. One time... we got horribly drunk. (They both laugh).
Your Grace. (Leaves).

4.text: Queen Daenerys. Tales of your beauty were not exaggerated.
Mine is one of the oldest and proudest families in Meereen.
My father, one of Meereen's most respected and beloved citizens, oversaw the restoration and maintenance of its greatest landmarks. This pyramid included.
You have, Your Grace. You crucified him. I pray you'll never live to see a member of your family treated so cruelly.
My father spoke out against crucifying those children. He decried it as a criminal act, but was overruled. Is it justice to answer one crime with another?
What's done is done. You are the queen and I am a servant of Meereen. A servant who does not wish to see its traditions eradicated.
The tradition of funeral rite. Proper burial in the Temple of the Graces. My father and 162 noble Meereenese are still nailed to those posts, carrion for vultures, rotting in the sun.
Your Grace, I ask that you order these men taken down so that they might receive proper burials.

Your Grace, I cannot defend the actions of the masters. I can only speak to you as a son who loved his father. Let me take his body down. Let me have him brought to the temple and buried with dignity so that he might find peace in the next world.
Thank you, my queen.

5.text: The mission to Yunkai was a resounding success. The Wise Masters of Yunkai have agreed to cede power to a council of elders, made up of both the freedmen and the former slaveholders. All matters of consequence will be brought to you for review.
They did ask for some concessions.
Politics is the art of compromise, your grace.
Forgive me. You’re right, of course. Still, it’s easier to rule happy subjects than angry ones.
They do not ask for the return of slavery. They ask for the re-opening of the fighting pits.
In the new world that you’ve brought to us, free men would fight free men.
The pitfighters that you liberated plead for this opportunity. Bring some here and ask them yourself.
Opening them would show the people of Yunkai and Meereen that you respect their traditions.
If you--
And the information you did get, he is young and poor.
Why should he want to bring back slavery? What did it do for him?
And how do you know this?
I don't know it, and I'm the head of a great family.
She should have cut off the traitor's head in the Great Pyramid and been done with it.
All men must die. But not all can die in glory.

Why else do men fight? Why did your ancestors cross the Narrow Sea and conquer the Seven Kingdoms? So their names would live on. Those who find victory in the fighting pits, will never become kings, but their names will live on. It's the best chance they'll ever have.
Your Grace, today is the traditional start of the fighting season.

Traditions are the only thing that will hold this city, your city, together. (Shots of Sons of the Harpy walking through tunnels with torches). Without them, former slaves and former masters have nothing in common. Nothing but centuries of mistrust and resentment. I can't promise this is the answer to all our problems, but it's a start.
I am so sorry, my queen. He was a good man.
But... I'm the leader of my family.
No, Your Grace! I had nothing to do with this. Your Grace!
(Valyrian) All men must die.
My, my queen, please do not do this.
I did not want to die a coward. Apparently I do not want to die at all. (Sniffles).
Yes, my queen.
For generations, in the days leading up to the great games, it has been customary for our ruler to make the rounds to the lower pits to pay the fighters there the honor of her presence.
Your Grace, it’s a tradition for the queen to stay until the victor has emerged.
Just making sure everything’s in order.
They’re waiting for you. Clap your hands.
Kings and queens never bet on the games. Perhaps you should go find someone who does.
I have spent much of my life in Meereen, and in my experience, larger men do triumph over smaller man, far more often than not.
You don’t approve?
Fair enough, yet -- it’s an unpleasant question -- but what great thing has ever been accomplished without killing or cruelty?
I’m not talking about myself. I’m talking about the necessary conditions of greatness.
That is a vital part of the great city of Meereen. Which has existed long before you arrived and will remain standing long after we have returned to the dirt.
At your command?
How many people will die to make this happen?
So your reasons are true, and theirs are false. They don’t know their own minds, but you do.
Your Grace--
She cannot.
Your Grace, Your Grace, come with me! I know a way out! I know a way--

4.text: (speaking Valyrian.) You heard her! She said she came to free us.
(speaking Valyrian.) She will protect us. She defeated the masters' champion.
(speaking Valyrian.) She has a great army. You want to live the rest of your days in chains?

5.text: They do not see us as people, Your Grace.
Make them very angry.
Sons of the Harpy, they want to put a collar back on my neck. On all of our necks. Please, Your Grace, you must kill him.
He is born free.
They pay him. Great families afraid to do a thing. They pay poor man to do it for them.
Everyone knows this.

I do not know the place from where Old Ser comes. Things maybe are different there, I hope. But here, in Meereen, before Daenerys Stormborn, they own us. So we learn much about them or we do not live long. They teach me what they are. Mercy, fair trial
For you, Mhysa. (kneels) You wanted the Harpy dead, but your hands were tied. I set you free, as you did all of us.
He would rather rip your city apart than see slaves lifted from the dirt.

Then who lives in the Pyramids? Who wears gold masks and murders your children? (beat) When Grey Worm came to us, I was the first to take up the knife for you. I remember the look on my father's face as I struck down his Master, who had traded his infant son for a dog. My father died in the fighting. If we allow the Sons of the Harpy to return us to chains, he never lived.
Mhysa, please! Forgive me!
Mhysa... (prays in Valyrian)

2.text: (dothraki) A house of ghosts, Khaleesi.
Where are the guards?
(Valerian) It was given to me by the Thirteen. The Elders of Qarth.
(Valerian) Three days to the east, on the sea.
(Valerian) They said they would be honored to receive the Mother of Dragons.
(Dothraki) Or melt it. Very simple.
(Dothraki) Of course not, Khaleesi! We will wait until we leave.
(Dothraki) Why not?

1.text: Khaleesi!
A trader from Garth told me that dragons come from the moon.

He told me the moon was an egg, Khaleesi, that once there were two moons in the sky. But one wandered too close to the sun and it cracked from the heat. Out of it poured a thousand thousand dragons and they drank the sun's fire.
Men like to talk when they're happy. Before your brother bought me for you, it was my job to make men happy.
I was nine when my mother sold me to the pleasure house.
I did not touch a man for three years, Khaleesi. First you must learn.
Yes.
No.
No, Khaleesi. You must look in his eyes always. Love comes in at the eyes. It is said that Irogenia of Lys could finish a man with nothing but her eyes.

Kings traveled across the world for a night with Irogenia. Magisters sold their palaces. Khals burned her enemies just to have her for a few hours. They say a thousand men proposed to her and she refused them all.

You will make him like it, Khaleesi. Men want what they've never had. And the Dothraki take slaves like a hound takes a bitch. Are you a slave, Khaleesi? Then don't make love like a slave. Very good, Khaleesi. Out there he is the mighty Khal, but in this tent, he belongs to you.
If he wanted the Dothraki way, why did he marry you?
Your Grace?
They call you the last dragon...
You have dragon's blood in your veins?
What happened to the dragons? I was told that brave men killed them all.
I have always wanted to see a dragon. There is nothing in the world that I would rather see.

They can fly. And wherever they are, just a few flaps of their wings and they're somewhere else... Far away. And they can kill. Anyone or anything that tries to hurt them gets burned away to nothing... melted... like so many candles. Seeing a dragon would make me very happy.
I was not locked in. I have seen things.

I've seen... A man from Asshai with a dagger of real dragonglass. I've seen a man who could change his face the way that other men change their clothes. And I've seen a pirate who wore his weight in gold and whose ship had sails of colored silk. So... Have you seen one?
A dragon.
What happened to the skulls?
That's very sad.
No, your Grace. To teach your sister.
Forgive me, Khaleesi. I did as you asked.
You have the honor of addressing Daenerys of the House Targaryen.
Khaleesi! Stop him!

2.text: What did your brother say about them, Khaleesi?
He didn't tell you what kind of meat?
Khaleesi, please. He said you'd never leave Qarth alive.
Please, Khaleesi, I beg you.
I beg you, please!
Please! Please!
Yes, Khaleesi.
Did you see the dress Xaro had made for you? They say he's the wealthiest man in Qarth.
And if Qarth is the wealthiest city in Essos
(chuckles) You would look like a real princess in Xaro's

1.text: Your hands.
Dragon gone, Khaleesi.
No dragon. Brave men kill them. It is known.
Moon is no egg. Moon is goddess... wife of sun. It is known.
Rakharo ask if you want him dead, Khaleesi.
Rakharo say you should take ear, to teach respect.
Yes, Khaleesi.
When was last time you bleed, Khaleesi? You change, Khaleesi. It’s a blessing from the Great Stallion.
The Khaleesi wants to eat something different tonight. Kill some rabbits.
Find some ducks, she likes ducks.
Dog then. I have seen many dogs.
The Khaleesi have baby inside her. It is true. She does not bleed for two moons. Her belly start to swell.
She does not want to eat horse.
Yes, Khaleesi.
Khaleesi?
Oh, Khaleesi!
Khaleesi!

2.text: No! (Speaking Dothraki, to Daenerys) They killed his soul!
(Speaking Dothraki) They did! They butchered him like an animal. They did not burn his body. (Daenerys kneels to Irri’s level). He can never join his ancestors in the night lands.
(Dothraki) I rewove this part of the top. And I fixed the heel on this one.
It is known.
(Dothraki) May he ride forever through the night lands.
She's not a princess. She's a Khaleesi. You should wear it, Khaleesi.
You are their guest. It would be rude not to.

1.text: (picking up the dragon eggs from their chest, speaking in Dothraki) ls this your command, Khaleesi? (Daenerys nods, Rakharo places the eggs next to Drogo’s funeral pyre)
You walk. [to Viserys]
Dothraki don’t wear steel dresses.
Armor. Armor make a man... Vroz?
Slow.
My father taught me how to fight. He taught me that speed defeats size.
He was bloodrider to Khal Bharbo. And your father, Jorah the Andal? He was a warrior also?
There are no rabbits.
Have you seen any ducks, woman? No rabbits, no ducks. Do you have eyes in your head? Do you?
A blessing from the Great Stallion.
Huh-uh, huh-uh.
Huh.
Lamb men make good slaves. Khal Drogo will make a gift of them to the slavers.
She is a lamb girl, Khaleesi. The riders do her honor.
Khaleesi, do not do this thing. Let me kill this witch.
This is blood magic. lt is forbidden.
(in Dothraki) Nothing good will come of this.
They will not come. They say she is cursed.
The witch - she can bring baby. l hear her say so.

2.text: (Speaking Dothraki) What do we seek, Khaleesi?
(Speaking Dothraki) I will not fail you, blood of my blood.
This is… bad time to start.

7.text: Father, Smith, Warrior, Mother, Maiden, Crone, Stranger. I am hers and she is mine from this day until the end of my days.

3.text: If I may, nephew, I encountered a situation with one of my lieutenants at the Stone Mill which may have some bearing--
Robb knows I meant him no disr--

My blunder sent Tywin's mad scurrying back to Casterly Rock with his tail between his legs. I think King Robb understands we're not gonna win this war if he's the only one winning any battles. No, there's glory enough to go around.
I seized an opportunity.
The Mountain was garrisoned across the river from it.
We took the fight to him. He could not withstand us.
We took hostages. Willem Lannister. Martyn Lannister.
No.
No.
But for every man we lost, the Lannisters--
I'm sorry. I didn't know.
Word of this can't leave Riverrun. They were Tywin Lannister's nephews. The Lannisters pay their debts. They never stop talking about it.
It wouldn't be lying. We will bury them and remain silent until the war is done.
A hostage. Tell the Karstarks that as long as they remain loyal, he will not be harmed.
I don't think that's--
What?
(chuckles) No.
How old is she?
Could I see her first?
Why should I let that old ferret choose my bride for me? At the very least, I should be offered the same choice you were. I'm his liege lord.
I didn't wound him. My answer is no.
The laws of gods and men are very clear. No man can compel another man to marry.
He's wanted me for one of his daughters since I was 12. He's not gonna stop wanting it now. When I say no, he will come back and offer me a daughter of my choosing.
I had something less permanent in mind.
I'll marry her.
He can take it as he likes. He's getting the wedding he wanted.
You’re a delight to me, my lady.
Ho-ho! Careful now, ladies. Once you set that monster free, there’s no caging him again [Laughs].

6.text: I have your word?
Oh, good. Good, that’s- - that’s a fine thing. My uncle will never surrender the castle, ser. Whatever game you’re playing.
A son I’ve never met born of a wife that I haven’t seen since our first night together.
Do you imagine yourself a decent person? Is that it? After you’ve massacred my family. Kept me in a cell for years. Stolen our lands.
Says the man who shoved his sword through his king’s back.
You understand. On some level you understand that you’re an evil man.
Well, that is convenient for you. You’re a fine-looking fellow, aren’t you?

Your square jaw, your golden armor. Tell me, I want to know. I truly do. How do you live with yourself? All of us have to believe that we’re decent, don’t we? You have to sleep at night. How do you tell yourself that you’re decent after everything that you’ve done?
Yeah. She should have killed you.
Do you think I care whom you admire and whom you don’t?
Oh. Oh, I see. You’re a madman.
Don’t talk about Cat!
You didn’t come here to talk about our sisters.
Edmure Tully, son of Hoster Tully, and the rightful Lord of Riverrun. I demand entry.
I demand entry.
Command all the forces within the castle to lay down their arms. Open the gates.
Your lord has given a command.
Find the Blackfish. Put him in irons and hand him over to the Freys.

8.text: My lords and ladies. I suppose this is the most important moment of our lives. What we decide today will reverberate through the annals of history. I stand before you as one of the senior lords in the country. A veteran of two wars. And I like to think my experience has led to some small skill in statecraft - and underst--
Maybe we should give the dogs a vote as well.
I suppose you want the crown.
Aye.

3.text: Why don't you shut your mouth about that damned mill? And don't call him "nephew." He is your king.
You're lucky I'm not your king. I wouldn't let you wave your blunders around like a victory flag.
Martyn is 15, I believe.
We seem to be running short of patience here.
It often comforts me to think that even in war's darkest days, in most places in the world absolutely nothing is happening.
Maybe? Your father was a stubborn old ox. I was surprised when he died. Didn't think death had the patience.

After 30 years of fighting, I don't think he remembered what started it. He asked me to stop calling myself Blackfish. He said it was an old joke and it was never funny to begin with. I told him people had been calling me Blackfish for so long, they don't remember my real name.

You mustn't think it. We don't know the truth. They could be in hiding. Robb believes they're alive. And he must go on believing. He's got to remain strong if he's to prevail. And you must remain strong for him.
Your father does realize we're in the middle of a war?
Listen to me and listen very carefully. You--
The laws of my fist are about to compel your teeth.
You recall that heroic engagement?
That rain will cost us another day.
Prickly? That what you call it? Might be the least pleasant man I've ever met.
I've seen wet shits I liked better than Walder Frey. Apologies, Your Grace. Spent too many years around lancers and pikemen.
(laughs)
Look at the crowd there.
The God’s love to reward a fool.
What? He’s my nephew, I love him. And he’s a damned fool.
That’s the point. [Still talking to ROOSE while the servant pours him more wine] Didn’t you marry one of these Frey girls?
Pardon, my lord, my lady. I need to find a tree to piss on.

6.text: Go on, then. Cut his throat.
Kingslayer.
I assume you’re here to fulfill the vow you gave my niece. I don’t see Sansa and Arya.
Pity. Do you wish to resume your captivity?
Then why are you here?
Or you’ll kill Edmure?
My nephew’s marked for death no matter what. Hang him and be done with it.
Hundreds of mine. Thousands of yours. If you can breach the walls.
Your honor? Bargaining with oathbreakers is like building on quicksand.

As long as I’m standing, the war is not over. This is my home. I was born in this castle and I’m ready to die in it. So you can either attack or try to starve us out. We have enough provisions for two years. Do you have two years, Kingslayer?
Sieges are dull. And I wanted to see you in person, get the measure of you.
Aye, now I have. I’m disappointed.
I’ve said no three times already.
I haven’t seen her since she was a child. I don’t know her signature. I don’t know you. And I will not surrender.
Double the guards tonight.
Yes, Brienne of Tarth. I know your father. A good man.
And if he were here now, I’d tell him the same I’m telling you.
If you think I’m abandoning my family’s seat on the Kingslayer’s word of honor, you’re a bloody fool.
We can stand longer than your one-handed friend thinks we can.
No?
Who gave you permission to cross the siege line and enter the castle? Who gave you that sword with the gold lion on the pommel?
She’s exactly like her mother.
I don’t have enough men to help her take Winterfell.
She wants her home back. I understand that. But this is my home. And if Jaime Lannister wants it, he can bloody well take it the way everyone else does.
Don’t let him in.

He’s been their captive ever since they murdered his king at the Red Wedding. Why do you think the people who murdered his king at the Red Wedding would decide to let him come home? Because it’s a trap, you idiot. Don’t let him in.
You’re not obeying Edmure’s commands. You’re obeying the fucking Kinglsayer’s commands.
WIth a knife to his throat. That is not a valid order.
I’ll have your head before I surrender Riverrun.
Go on.
I’ve run before from the Red Wedding. I’m not running again. This is my family home.
You’ll serve Sansa far better than I ever could.
Go on, now.
I haven’t had a proper sword fight in years. I expect I’ll make a damn fool of myself.

3.text: Lord Edmure, I hope I’m not a disappointment to you.
Kiss me, child.
It's so good of you to visit me and my foolish flock of hens. We're very sorry for your losses.
Gallant, yes. And charming and very clean. He knew how to dress and smile and somehow this gave him the notion he was fit to be king.
Loras is young and very good at knocking men off horses with a stick. That does not make him wise. As to your fathead father-

She might think we have some wits about us. One of us, at any rate. It was treason. I warned them. Robert has two sons and Renly has an older brother. How could he possibly have any claim to that ugly iron chair? We should have stayed well out of all this if you ask me. But once the cow's been milked, there's no squirting the cream back up her udders. So here we are to see things through. What do you say to that, Sansa? Shall we have some lemon cakes?
So we've been told. (To the SERVANT) Are you going to bring the food or do you mean to starve us to death? Here, Sansa, come sit with me. I'm much less boring than these others.
Do you know my son? The Lord of Highgarden?

No great pleasure, believe me. A ponderous oaf. His father was an oaf as well. My husband, the late Lord Luthor. He managed to ride off a cliff whilst hawking. They say he was looking up at the sky and paying no mind to where his horse was taking him. And now my son is doing the same, only this time he's riding a lion instead of a horse. Now I want you to tell me the truth about this royal boy, this Joffrey.
You, you. Who else would know better? We've heard some troubling tales. Is there any truth to them? Has this boy mistreated you?
Has he ripped out your tongue?
Yes, all Lannisters are lions. And when a Tyrell farts, it smells like a rose. But how kind is he? How clever? Has he a good heart, a gentle hand?
Bring me some cheese.
The cheese will be served when I want it served. And I want it served now.
Are you frightened, child? No need for that. We're only women here. Tell us the truth. No harm will come to you.
Yes, he had that reputation. And they named him traitor and took his head.
Go on.
Speak freely, child. We would never betray your confidence, I swear it.
Ah. That's a pity.
Have no fear. The Lord Oaf of Highgarden is determined that Margaery shall be queen. Even so, we thank you for the truth. Ah, here comes my cheese.
There appears to be a good deal of room elsewhere on the premises for everyone else.
No, the rest are there to look adoringly upon the 700 to remind them how superior they must be to have the best seats.
You were married here, Your Grace?
Must seem like only yesterday.
Your husband, was he buried here as well?
Such a tragedy.
I should say not. My son's a hunter. It helps him forget he's never been within a mile of a real battle.
All he laid siege to was the banquet table in the command tent.

I told him to stay out of Robert's rebellion. He had no business fighting an actual warrior. We mothers do what we can to keep our sons from the grave. But they do seem to yearn for it. We shower them with good sense, and it slides right off like rain off a wing.
A ridiculous arrangement, to my mind.

Another golden rose. How original. I eat from plates stamped with roses. I sleep in sheets embroidered with roses. I have a golden rose painted on my chamber pot, as if that makes it smell any better. Roses are boring, dear. 'Growing strong.' Ha! The dullest words of any house. 'Winter is coming!' Now that's memorable. 'We do not sow.' Strong. Strong. Those are houses you watch out for. Direwolves and krakens, fierce beasts. But a golden rose growing strong--ha, that strikes fear in the heart.
Look, little loves. A spider in the garden. Run along now. Grow strong.
The city is made brighter by my presence? Is that your usual line, Lord Varys? Are you here to seduce me?

Oh, no, please. Seduce away. It's been so long. Though I rather think it's all for naught. What happens when the nonexistent bumps against the decrepit? A question for the philosophers. But you've come mincing all this way for something. So?
No. Come, I've heard you're such a clever man. I'm curious why you've sought me out.
Have I? Because I spoke to her once in this garden and one of your little spies came running to tell you? Why shouldn't I take an interest? She's an interesting girl.
No, not particularly. But she's had an interesting childhood.
Come, come. You surrender rather easily. Walk with me. I know the walls have ears, but apparently the shrubbery does, too.
Which is Sansa Stark?
Yes. Ned Stark had many admirers, and how many stepped forward when the executioner came for his head?
How?
That's hardly surprising. She's a beautiful girl with a famous name.
It almost feels as if you're about to arrive at the point.
And why have you come to me with this matter?
(laughs)
And if Littlefinger marries her, he'll have the key in his pocket.
You must despise him. You're working so hard to undermine him.
You are a clever man, Lord Varys.
One doesn't need to be clever for that. It's all rather obvious, isn't it?
Gods, boy, that's enough. We're not in a tavern.
No need to speak. Are there any figs? Fetch some. I always take figs midafternoon. They help move the bowels. To what do I owe this summons?
I climbed all those steps to discuss financial matters?
Naturally.
What good is the word extravagant if it can't be used to describe a royal wedding?
Good.
And?
Oh, I'd nearly forgotten.

I can't think how it slipped my mind. What is it, 12,000 infantrymen the Tyrell family has supplied? 2,000 in support. Provisions so this city might survive the winter. A million bushels of wheat. Half a million bushels each of barley, oats, and rye. 20,000 head of cattle. 50,000 sheep. You don't have to lecture me about wartime expenses. I'm quite familiar with them.

As is a royal wedding. The people are hungry for more than just food. They crave distractions. And if we don't provide them, they'll create their own. And their distractions are likely to end with us being torn to pieces. A royal wedding is much safer. Wouldn't you say?
And traditionally paid for by the royal family.
I was told you were drunk, impertinent, and thoroughly debauched. You can imagine my disappointment at finding nothing but a browbeaten bookkeeper. Where did you go for them, Volantis?
Oh, very well. I won't have it said that House Tyrell refuses to play its part. We'll pay for half the expenses and the celebrations will go on as planned. Is that sufficient?
Very good, then. That's settled. Good day.
Impossible.
My grandson is the pride of Highgarden. The most desirable bachelor in all seven kingdoms. Your daughter--
Old.

Old. I'm something of an expert on the subject. Her change will be upon her before long. I'll spare you the details of what will happen then. You men may have a stomach for bloodshed and slaughter, but this is another matter entirely.
Oh, not at all. A sword swallower through and through.
Did you grow up with boy cousins, Lord Tywin? Sons of your father's bannermen, squires, stable boys?
And you never--
Not once? Not in any way?
I congratulate you upon your restraint. But it's a natural thing, two boys having a go at each other beneath the sheets.
I wouldn't say that. True, we don't tie ourselves in knots over a discreet bit of buggery, but brothers and sisters-- where I come from, that stain would be very difficult to wash out.
Lie or not, you must admit many people find it quite convincing. Convincing enough to put swords in their hands and send them off to kill Lannisters and Tyrells thanks to our new affiliation.
As an authority on myself, I must disagree.
And if Cersei is too old to give Loras children, we're throwing another prized flower into the dirt. It is a chance we simply cannot take.
Oh
You would have your grandson protected by someone who disgusts you?
It's a rare enough thing-- a man who lives up to his reputation.

So their son will be your nephew. After you're wed to Cersei, of course. And you will be the king's stepfather and brother-in-law. When you marry the king, Joffrey's mother will become his sister-in-law and your son will be Loras' nephew? Grandson? I'm not sure. But your brother will become your father-in-law. That much is beyond dispute.

4.text: No. No. You're a queen, not an ox.
Your grandfather gave me a necklace just like this one for my 51st nameday.
Nonsense.
My little dears. Go and speak to the jewelers of King's Landing. Tell them who you are, tell them who sent you. The one who brings me the best necklace will get to keep the next best.
The Margaery Tyrell who walks into the sept a fortnight from now will inspire 1,000 songs. Now, how sad it will be if she's wearing rubbish like that.
You watch that. Even here, even with me.
My word.
We know who you are. We've heard all about you. But hearing is one thing. Aren't you just marvelous? Absolutely singular.
I hear you knocked my grandson into the dirt like the silly little boy he is.
You dare not refuse.
It feels proportionate.
The expected extravagance.
You ought to try enjoying something before you die. You might find it suits you.
Not now, Mace. Lord Tywin and I are speaking.
Anyway, I don't know what you're complaining about. I'm paying my share.

No, your heartfelt thank-you is it's own reward. I would imagine I'd be hearing it again before long. Wars are rather expensive. "The Iron Bank will have it's due." How they love to remind everyone. Almost as much as you Lannisters with your debts.
We both know you're smarter than that. Come, Tywin, let us celebrate young love.

You look exquisite, child. The wind has been at you, though. I haven't had the opportunity to tell you how sorry I was to hear about your brother. War is war, but killing a man at a wedding, horrid. What sort of monster would do such a thing? As if men need more reasons to fear marriage.

Lord Tyrion, you see? Not as bad as all that. Perhaps if your pauper husband were to sell his mule and his last pair of shoes, he might be able to afford to bring you to Highgarden for a visit. Now that peace has come and all is right with the world, it would do you good to see some of it. You must excuse me. It's time I ate some of this food I paid for.
Help the poor boy.
Idiots, help your king. -

More than you were with Renly. Less than you would have been if Joffrey had done you the courtesy of consummating the marriage before dying. In any case, this would not be an opportune moment to press the issue.
The world is overflowing with horrible things. But they're all a tray of cakes next to death. They brought me your grandfather's body when he died, you know? Made me look at it.

They took me to the Great Hall and there he was. The man I'd married and suffered to father my children. A great doughy lump I'd sat next to at endless dinners and tedious gatherings. There he was... lying on a table.
Nonsense. Your circumstances have improved markedly. You may not have enjoyed watching him die, but you enjoyed it more than you would have enjoyed being married to him, I can promise you that.
Our alliance with the Lannisters remains every bit as necessary to them as it is unpleasant for us. You did wonderful work on Joffrey. The next one should be easier.

The time has come, my dear. There's nothing more tedious than a trial. Except perhaps these gardens. If I have to take one more leisurely stroll through these gardens, I'll fling myself from the cliffs.
Have you been to see Tommen yet?

I wasn't originally meant to marry your grandfather Luthor, you know. He was engaged to my sister, your great-aunt Viola. I was to be given to some Targaryen or other. Marrying a Targaryen was all the rage back then. But the momentI saw my intended, with his twitchy little ferret's face and ludicrous silver hair, I knew he wouldn't do. So the evening before Luthor was to propose to my sister, I got lost on my way back from my embroidery lesson and happened upon his chamber.
How absentminded of me.
The following morning, Luthor never made it down the stairs to propose to my sister 'cause the boy couldn't bloody walk.

And once he could, the only thing he wanted was what I'd given him the night before. I was good. I was very, very good. You are even better. But you need to act quickly. Cersei may be vicious, but she's not stupid. She'll turn the boy against you as soon as she can. And by the time you're married, it'll be too late. Luckily for you ,the Queen Regent is rather distracted at the moment, mourning her dear departed boy. Accusing her brother of his murder, which he didn't commit.
He could have done,but he didn't.
But I do know. You don't think I'd let you marry that beast, do you?
Shh. Don't you worry yourself about all that. You just do what needs to be done.

5.text: Oh! You can smell the shit from 5 miles away. Well, why are we stopped, go on.
Rumors and gossip, that’s all they got. It’s theater, nothing more. If they arrested all the pillow biters in King’s Landing there’d be no room left in the dungeons for anyone else.
Renly Baratheon shagged half the stable boys in the Seven Kingdoms. Everyone knew. No one cared.
And Loras is the queen’s brother. No, no, no, no, this is unacceptable.
Of course she is. She wants to drag our names through the dirt. Put us in our place. Get some rest, dear, you look appalling. Let me deal with Cersei Lannister.
Your Grace, I have travelled a long way.
Put the pen down, dear, we all know you aren’t writing anything.
And the famous tart Queen Cersei.
I know you’re behind this absurd incarceration of my grandson.
You’ll get your apology when I get Loras.
Has the crown suddenly stopped needing the troops, gold, and wheat my house supplies?
Do you expect the alliance to continue after you’ve thrown our future into prison?
What veil?
I didn’t trust your father. I didn’t particularly like him. But I respected him. He was no fool. He understood that sometimes we must work with our rivals rather than destroy them.
Well I think that’s quite enough of that.
What are you doing? Let us pass.
You there! Where would I find the High Septon, or High Sparrow, or whatever bloody fool name he’s got.
You should have the decency to stand when you talk to a lady.
Don’t spar with me little fellow.
Hips.
A man of the people, is that your game? It’s an old game. dull and unconvincing. A man of the people who does Cersei’s dirty work for her.
Spare me the homilies, I can smell a fraud from a mile away.
I’m here for my grandson and granddaughter.
Don’t you walk away from me.
What is it you want? Gold? I’ll make you the richest septon who ever lived.
What then?
How do they communicate their demands? By raven or horse?

Half the men, women, and children in this foul city break the sacred laws. You live among murderers, thieves, and rapists. And yet you punish Loras for shagging and Margaery for defending her brother?
If it’s equality you want then so be it. When House Tyrell stops sending our crops to the capital, everyone here will starve. And I’ll make sure the hungry know who to blame,
No you’re not.
Not for your clientele, clearly.
You’ve always been rather impressed with yourself, haven’t you?
Don’t pretend to have any concern for my house, my grandchildren, or me. I should have known you’d return to the capital once things started going wrong.

I promise you, Lord Baelish, that our fates are joined. Together we murdered a king. And if my house should fall, I would have nothing to hide. And if i should meet with some accident here at this broken little flesh market, they’ll never even find what’s left of you. So do you deny a part in all of this?
And what did she want?
What kind of gift?

6.text: The last time a Tyrell came to Dorne, he was assassinated. 100 red scorpions, was it?
You murder your own prince, but you expect me to trust you?
What is your name again? Barbaro?
Obara. You look like an angry little boy. Don’t presume to tell me what I need.
Do shut up, dear.
Anything from you?
No? Good. Let the grown women speak.
Cersei stole the future from me. She killed my son. She killed my grandson. She killed my granddaughter. Survival is not what I’m after now.
And what is my heart’s desire?
He’s beaten us. That’s what’s happening.
Does it move or talk? I want to speak with you alone.
Oh, this is madness!
...until I tell them to stop. If I tell them to stop. You could use a good bashing.
What have they done to you?
We marched for you.
And what about your brother? What mercy did they show him?
Have you lost your mind?
He is the heir to Highgarden, the future of House Tyrell.
As a mindless fanatic.
You will leave for Highgarden today. There is no law that says you must stay here.
I will never leave you. Never.
I’ll see you soon, my dear.
That is hardly your concern.
Loras rots in a cell because of you. THe High Sparrow rules this city because of you. Our two ancient houses face collapse because of you and your stupidity.
Good.

I wonder if you’re the worst person I’ve ever met. At a certain age, it’s hard to recall. But the truly vile do stand out through the years. Do you remember the way you smirked at me when my grandson and granddaughter were dragged off to their cells? I do. I’ll never forget it.
I’m leaving this wretched city as fast as I can before that shoeless zealot throws me into one of his cells. If you’re half as bright as you think you are, you’ll find your way out of here, too.

What’ll you do, then? You have no support. Not anymore. Your brother’s gone. The High Sparrow saw to that. The rest of your family have abandoned you. The people despise you. You’re surrounded by enemies, thousands of them. You’re going to kill them all by yourself? You’ve lost, Cersei. It’s the only joy I can find in all this misery.

7.text: That's very nice to hear. Of course, I can't remember a queen who was better loved than my grand daughter. The common people loved her, the nobles loved her. And what is left of her now? Ashes. Commoners, nobles, they're all just children really. They won't obey you unless they fear you.
So, your master plan is to use our armies? Forgive me for asking, but why did you bother to bring your own?
Peace. Do you think that's what we had under your father or his father or his? Peace never lasts, my dear. Would you take a bit of advice from an old woman?

He's a clever man, your Hand. I've known a great many clever men. I've outlived them all. Do you know why? I ignored them. The lords of Westeros are sheep. Are you a sheep? No. You're a dragon. Be a dragon.
It's done?
And now the rains weep for our whores. Did we fight well?
It was never our forte. Golden roses indeed. Your brother and his new queen thought you would be defending Casterly Rock.
So you'll just let them take it?
And you took your army, your real army, and went where they weren't?
Yes. You must be very wise by now.

If he was so clever why didn't he take Highgarden the moment your gold mines ran dry? I suppose I'll be able to ask him myself soon enough. No more learning from my mistakes, eh? How will you do it? With that sword?
That was Joffrey's sword, wasn't it? Not that he ever used it. What did he call it?

He really was a cunt, wasn't he? I did unspeakable things to protect my family, or watched them being done on my orders. I never lost a night's sleep over them. They were necessary. And whatever I imagined necessary for the safety of House Tyrell I did. But your sister has done things I wasn't capable of imagining. That was my prize mistake, a failure of imagination. She's a monster, you do know that?
You love her. You really do love her. You poor fool. She'll be the end of you.

What better person to discuss it with? What better guarantee could you have that the things you say will never leave this room? But perhaps you're right. If she's driven you this far it's gone beyond your control.
She's a disease. I regret my role in spreading it. You will too.
How will it happen?
Will there be pain?
That's good.

I'd hate to die like your son clawing at my neck, foam and bile spilling from my mouth, eyes blood red, skin purple. It must have been horrible for you as a Kingsguard, as a father. It was horrible enough for me. A shocking scene. Not at all what I intended. You see, I'd never seen the posion work before. Tell Cersei. I want her to know it was me.

4.text: From House Tyrell and the people of the Reach, Your Grace, it is my honor to present you with this wedding cup.
May you and my daughter Margaery drink deep and live long.
I shall be honored, Your Grace.
Lord Tywin and I already determined that I shall be the Master of Ships long before you--
Lord Tywin, it's a great honor to have been granted a seat on this council. I--
Your own brother said this to you?
Do you remember the precise nature of this threat?
And he said this to you at a meeting of the small council?
I beg your pardon? You said you were his...

5.text: Your Grace, I would be willing to serve provisionally as the King's Hand until he becomes old enough--
Oh, Your Grace.
The honor is all mine, Your Grace.
High Septon, this is a rather shocking thing to hear.
The Iron Bank has called one tenth of the Crown's debts. Given the expense of rebuilding the royal -
With winter coming, half what they ask. Less.
Well, House Tyrell could front the gold, and the the Crown will pay us back in time, or I'll have words with my daughter.
Absolutely.
(After a moment, looks at her surprised). Me? (Qyburn smiles).
I will be honored, Your Grace.
My very own Kingsguard? Please express -
(Raises his hands). Of course, of course, (Gathers his belongings, and then gets up). I'll give your regards to the Titan of Braavos.
Bit of chop the last few days but nothing too awful. Good to see the old chap is still guarding the Harbor.
Vintnors say this might be the best year for red grapes in half a century. If we come to a satisfactory arrangement, I’ll be sure to send the Arbor’s finest your way.
Some consider usury distasteful, dishonorable. Pure nonsense, of course.
Did you know that at one point Maegor the third tried to outlaw it in the Seven Kingdoms? Wanted to arrest anyone caught charging interest and cut off both their hands.
If a man charges low interest on a loan then he has nothing to gain and everything to lose, so why charge him? Whereas a reward makes a man willing to gamble.
You are the world's best gamblers. And all those bets you won built this.
Oh, nonsense. Work's over. Do you sing?

It's not a gift, it’s a skill, anyone can learn it. “So give me a kiss by the Long Canall and give me two kisses in Salty Town, for we are going to die, tomorrow. The bareheaded beggar, the king with his crown…”

6.text: No, I can’t let them…
My mother...
My lord.
My friends, the hour has come. Madness has overtaken this city and grasped in its claws my children. But now we must drive it back under the rocks whence it came. Madness has had its day!
What’s happening?

1.text: I owe you my life, Ser.
Lord Stark's lucky he still has a head.
You're jealous.
Only if I slip.
Mhmm.
I want you.
Hold still.
You did vomit when that boy's eye was knocked out in the mêlée.
He shouldn't have entered the mêlée if he didn't know how to fight.
It's not a gift. No one gave it to me. I'm good because I work at it -- every day of my life since I could hold a stick.
Yes well, I guess we'll never know.
Everywhere. So how did it end up? The Targaryen girl will die?
It's a shame he can't muster the same enthusiasm for his wife.
I have an outrageous amount of money.
But a lot more than you.
Hmm... How did that ever happen?
Do you know who should be King?
I am. My father could be your bank. I've never fought in a war before, but I'd fight for you.
And where was Robert in the line of royal succession? Joffrey is a monster. Tommen is eight.
Stannis has the personality of a lobster.
Look at it.

It's just blood. We've all got it in us. Sometimes a little spills. If you become King, you're going to see a lot of this. You need to get used to it. Go on. Look. People love you. They love to serve you because you're kind to them. They want to be near you.

You're willing to do what needs to be done, but you don't gloat over it. You don't love killing. Where is it written that power is the sole province of the worst? That thrones are only made for the hated and the feared. You would be a wonderful King.

2.text: Your Grace, my sister Margaery, her husband was taken from us before . . . She remains innocent. I would ask you to find it in your heart to do us the great honor of joining our houses.
Yield! I yield.
Has your son marched against Tywin Lannister yet?
If Robb Stark wants a pact with us, he should come himself, not hide behind his mother's skirts.
A member of the Kingsguard? As if I wasn't humiliated enough already.
Jealous? Of Brienne the Beauty? Don't make me laugh.
No, Your Grace. Not tonight. There's another Tyrell who requires your attention. You didn't win my father's support or his army on charm alone.
Your vassals are starting to snigger behind your back. Brides aren't usually virgins two weeks after their wedding night.
Officially. Shall I bring her to you?
Get out.
And you want that privilege for yourself.
Ride back to Highgarden, sister. I'm not running from Stannis.
I don't believe that. You don't believe that. Who gained the most from our king's death?
I will put a sword through his righteous face.
He would have been a true king, a good king.
Revenge.

3.text: Your Grace.
Yes.
Margaery does a great deal of work with the poor back in Highgarden.
Lady Sansa.
My sister Margaery invites you to take the air with her and our grandmother the Lady Olenna in the gardens. May I escort you to them?
I believe you grow more beautiful every day, Lady Sansa.
Of course I did.
I'll take my leave. Lady Sansa.
Squire!
That was no fight. I don't know you.
(chuckles)
How did you know?
That I wanted to.
My lord I'll have you know I'm to be married soon and even my intended hasn't the slightest notion.
You have a good deal of experience, do you?
Oh, it's more of a brooch, really. Though I suppose a brooch is a sort of pin, so
Uh, yes. I-I am as well.

Yes, me, too. Definitely. I've dreamed of a large wedding since I was quite young. The guests, the food, the tournaments. And the bride, of course. The most beautiful bride in the world in a beautiful gown of gold and green brocade with fringed sleeves. Have you ever been to Highgarden, my lady?
It's terrible, isn't it? The most terrible place there is.
Well, my father once told me--

4.text: Ser Jaime, I'm very sorry.
As does yours.
Yes, very much.
They certainly are.
And neither will you.

5.text: It was such a deep, deep shock to us all. Your father was a force to be reckoned with. He truly was. I wouldn’t presume to claim to have known him as such…
But just being in his presence was enough to make it so clear just how formidable a person you were dealing with. What a… what a force to be reckoned with.
No it doesn’t.
Sandstone.
Fine.
It’s Dorne.
Judging by my experience, that would be wonderful. Dorne, Highgarden. Anywhere but here.
You’re very respectful.
Why? They all know about me anyway. Everybody knows everything about everyone. What’s the point in trying to keep a secret in a place like this?
My intended? Please. Tywin’s dead. That means no one can force Cersei to marry me.
Unlucky you.
If she doesn’t marry me, she doesn’t go to Highgarden. Which means she stays in King’s Landing. Which means you’re trapped here with Cersei Lannister as your mother-by-law.
Perhaps?
Get your hands off of me.
Who do you think you are?
I don’t pay attention to rumors.
He was my friend. He was my king.
I was wrong to support Renly’s claim. I know that. But I was forgiven by Joffrey. I fought for him at the Battle of the Blackwater.
Why does it matter what I wore?
Of course I deny them.
Never.
Never.
Liar! He’s a liar!
Liar!

6.text: There’ll be no need for a trial. I confess before the Seven and freely admit to my crimes.
All of them. I lay with other men including the traitor Renly Baratheon.
I perjured myself before the gods. I am guilty of depravity… dishonesty, profligacy, and arrogance. I see that now. I humble myself before the Seven and accept whatever punishment the gods deem just.

I take full responsibility for my many sins and unburden myself of my desires. My only remaining wish is to devote my life to the Seven. May I be a living example of their grace for others to witness.
I do. I will abandon the Tyrell name and all that goes with it. I will renounce my lordship and my claims on Highgarden. I will never marry and I will never father children.
I will.
I can’t stay strong. I never was strong.
I don’t care about that.
I just want it to stop. Help me.
Let them win. Just make it stop. Please.
That’s enough of that.
Not fat enough already?
I read your letter. You’re to be a maester.
I thought the Night’s Watch might make a man of you. Something resembling a man at least. You managed to stay soft and fat.
Your nose buried in books. Spending your life reading about the achievements of better men. I’ll wager you still can’t sit a horse or wield a sword.
Your way down to Castle Black? Where did he kill a white walker? Where are you from? How’d you come to meet my son?
Where?
North of the Wall? You’re a Wildling. The Seven Kingdoms have waged war against these savages for centuries and here I sit hosting one in my hall thanks to my son. See that sword?

It’s called Heartsbane. It’s been in our family for 500 years. It’s Valyrian steel. Only a handful of them left in the world. It’s supposed to go to my firstborn son after I die. To him. He will never wield that sword. If he were to become Lord Tarly of Horn Hill, it would be the end of this house. I took you for a Mole’s Town whore when I saw you and I made my peace with that. Who else would have him? But I overestimated him. No. It was a wildling whore that seduced my son. This you getting back at me, boy? Hmm? Bring that to my table and making me dine with it. And you got what you were after, didn’t you? A bastard. A half-breed bastard. Your invitation into our home.
He dishonors us.

Your mother’s a fine woman. You’re not worthy of her. To please her, I’ll take the wildling in. She can work in the kitchens. The bastard will be raised here. But this will be the last night you ever spend at Horn Hill.

7.text: She has three full-grown dragons, Your Grace. The same as Aegon when he conquered the Seven Kingdoms. How do you propose to stop them?
Ser, Jaime. I believe you know my son.
If my queen summons me, I answer the call. And I've heard what she does to those that defy her.
I have an army to mobilize. It won't be long until the fighting starts.
It's a long ride back to the reach, Ser Jaime. How may I serve?

Including Olenna Tyrell? I'm a Tarley. That name means something. We're not oath breakers. We're not schemers. We don't stab our rivals in the back or cut their throats at weddings. I swore an oath to House Tyrell.
I've known Olenna since I was a child.
The granaries are being emptied and loaded into wagons, My Lord.
My Lord.
All of the gold is safely through the gates of King's Landing.
We need to get the last of these wagons over the Blackwater Rush before nightfall. If the head of the line is ambushed, the tail will never be able to reinforce in time.
With your permission, flogging stragglers has a marked effect on mobility.
Come on, lads. Not those wagons. Fall in line. Fall in line.
Spears armed!
I already have a queen.

There are no easy choices in war. Say what you will about your sister, she was born in Westeros, has lived here all her life. You on the other hand, you murdered your own father and chose to support a foreign invader. One with no ties to this land, an army of savages at her back.
You cannot send me to the Wall. You are not my queen.
Step back and shut your mouth.
A stupid boy.

6.text: Sam. Oh, Sam.
I never thought I’d see you again. You look wonderful.
That’s enough, Talla.
Oh, my. You are lovely.
Hello, little one. It’s me, your grandmother.
May I hold him?
They’re on a hunt. They’ll join us for dinner. Come inside. Such a journey. You must be exhausted.
I imagine it’s common where you’re from. We once met a man, Lord Umber from Last Hearth, wasn’t it, Randyll, who said he taught all his daughters how to hunt.
Samwell, would you care for more bread?
Randyll, to be maester of the Night’s Watch is a great honor.
Come, my dear. Talla.
I’ve lost my appetite.
You dishonor yourself.
Father says I have to marry Symun Fossoway. He has yellow teeth- -

Come, you’ll be wanting a bath after all that travel. Oh, and a dress for dinner. You can wear one of mine. What’s your color? Midnight blue or silver? Silver, maybe. Come. You can choose one of my bedrooms if you want.
Your father taught you to hunt? Our father would never teach us. I think our father could learn a thing or two from your father.
Well, no. We haven’t been able to cure that one yet. This is last week’s.
Brought it down from 70 yards. One shot.
So do you do much hunting up at the wall?
Mm-hmmm. Mostly deer or is it elk as well?
There’s no such thing.

7.text: Ser, Jaime.
Dickon.
We have teams of men collecting it and more farmers in the Reach.
My Lord.
Ser Jaime.
Dickon.
It was glorious.
All my life we've been pledged to House Tyrell. I knew some of those men. I hunted with them.
I didn't expect it to smell like that.
You will have to kill me too.
I'm Dickon Tarley, son of Randyll Tarley.
I will not.
